verses.textEn: Paul, called as an Apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God; and Sosthenes, a brother:
verses.textLa: Paulus vocatus Apostolus Iesu Christi per voluntatem Dei, et Sosthenes frater,

verses.textEn: to the Church of God which is at Corinth, to those sanctified in Christ Jesus, called to be saints with all who are invoking the name of our Lord Jesus Christ in every place of theirs and of ours.
verses.textLa: Ecclesiæ Dei, quæ est Corinthi, sanctificatis in Christo Iesu, vocatis sanctis, cum omnibus, qui invocant nomen Domini nostri Iesu Christi, in omni loco ipsorum, et nostro.

verses.textEn: Grace and peace to you from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: Gratia vobis, et pax a Deo Patre nostro, et Domino Iesu Christo.

verses.textEn: I give thanks to my God continuously for you because of the grace of God that has been given to you in Christ Jesus.
verses.textLa: Gratias ago Deo meo semper pro vobis in gratia Dei, quæ data est vobis in Christo Iesu:

verses.textEn: By that grace, in all things, you have become wealthy in him, in every word and in all knowledge.
verses.textLa: quod in omnibus divites facti estis in illo, in omni verbo, et in omni scientia:

verses.textEn: And so, the testimony of Christ has been strengthened in you.
verses.textLa: sicut testimonium Christi confirmatum est in vobis:

verses.textEn: In this way, nothing is lacking to you in any grace, as you await the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: ita ut nihil vobis desit in ulla gratia, expectantibus revelationem Domini nostri Iesu Christi,

verses.textEn: And he, too, will strengthen you, even until the end, without guilt, until the day of the advent of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: qui et confirmabit vos usque in finem sine crimine, in die adventus Domini nostri Iesu Christi.

verses.textEn: God is faithful. Through him, you have been called into the fellowship of his Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.textLa: Fidelis Deus: per quem vocati estis in societatem Filii eius, Iesu Christi Domini nostri.

verses.textEn: And so, I beg you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that every one of you speak in the same way, and that there be no schisms among you. So may you become perfect, with the same mind and with the same judgment.
verses.textLa: Obsecro autem vos fratres per nomen Domini nostri Iesu Christi: ut idipsum dicatis omnes, et non sint in vobis schismata: sitis autem perfecti in eodem sensu, et in eadem sententia.

verses.textEn: For it has been indicated to me, about you, my brothers, by those who are with Chloes, that there are contentions among you.
verses.textLa: Significatum est enim mihi de vobis fratres mei ab iis, qui sunt Chloes, quia contentiones sunt inter vos.

verses.textEn: Now I say this because each of you is saying: “Certainly, I am of Paul;” “But I am of Apollo;” “Truly, I am of Cephas;” as well as: “I am of Christ.”
verses.textLa: Hoc autem dico, quod unusquisque vestrum dicit: Ego quidem sum Pauli: ego autem Apollo: ego vero Cephæ: ego autem Christi.

verses.textEn: Has Christ been divided? Was Paul crucified for you? Or were you baptized in the name of Paul?
verses.textLa: Divisus est Christus? Numquid Paulus crucifixus est pro vobis? Aut in nomine Pauli baptizati estis?

verses.textEn: I give thanks to God that I have baptized none of you, except Crispus and Gaius,
verses.textLa: Gratias ago Deo, quod neminem vestrum baptizavi, nisi Crispum, et Caium:

verses.textEn: lest anyone say that you have been baptized in my name.
verses.textLa: ne quis dicat quod in nomine meo baptizati estis.

verses.textEn: And I also baptized the household of Stephanus. Other than these, I do not recall if I baptized any others.
verses.textLa: Baptizavi autem et Stephanæ domum: ceterum nescio si quem alium baptizaverim.

verses.textEn: For Christ did not send me to baptize, but to evangelize: not through the wisdom of words, lest the cross of Christ become empty.
verses.textLa: Non enim misit me Christus baptizare, sed evangelizare: non in sapientia verbi, ut non evacuetur crux Christi.

verses.textEn: For the Word of the Cross is certainly foolishness to those who are perishing. But to those who have been saved, that is, to us, it is the power of God.
verses.textLa: Verbum enim crucis pereuntibus quidem stultitia est: iis autem, qui salvi fiunt, id est nobis, Dei virtus est.

verses.textEn: For it has been written: “I will perish the wisdom of the wise, and I will reject the discernment of the prudent.”
verses.textLa: Scriptum est enim: Perdam sapientiam sapientium, et prudentiam prudentium reprobabo.

verses.textEn: Where are the wise? Where are the scribes? Where are the truth-seekers of this age? Has not God made the wisdom of this world into foolishness?
verses.textLa: Ubi sapiens? Ubi scriba? Ubi conquisitor huius sæculi? Nonne stultam fecit Deus sapientiam huius mundi?
verses.notes: The word ‘conquisitor’ refers to those who search for something, and the prefix ‘con’ intensifies the meaning of the word, making it an intense search, and the context of the verse makes it a search for wisdom and truth. Hence the translation: truth-seekers.

verses.textEn: For the world did not know God through wisdom, and so, in the wisdom of God, it pleased God to accomplish the salvation of believers, through the foolishness of our preaching.
verses.textLa: Nam quia in Dei sapientia non cognovit mundus per sapientiam Deum: placuit Deo per stultitiam prædicationis salvos facere credentes.

verses.textEn: For the Jews ask for signs, and the Greeks seek wisdom.
verses.textLa: Quoniam et Iudæi signa petunt, et Græci sapientiam quærunt:

verses.textEn: But we are preaching Christ crucified. Certainly, to the Jews, this is a scandal, and to the Gentiles, this is foolishness.
verses.textLa: nos autem prædicamus Christum crucifixum: Iudæis quidem scandalum, Gentibus autem stultitiam,

verses.textEn: But to those who have been called, Jews as well as Greeks, the Christ is the virtue of God and the wisdom of God.
verses.textLa: ipsis autem vocatis Iudæis, atque Græcis Christum Dei virtutem, et Dei sapientia:

verses.textEn: For what is foolishness to God is considered wise by men, and that which is weakness to God is considered strong by men.
verses.textLa: quia quod stultum est Dei, sapientius est hominibus: et quod infirmum est Dei, fortius est hominibus.

verses.textEn: So take care of your vocation, brothers. For not many are wise according to the flesh, not many are powerful, not many are noble.
verses.textLa: Videte enim vocationem vestram fratres, quia non multi sapientes secundum carnem, non multi potentes, non multi nobiles:

verses.textEn: But God has chosen the foolish of the world, so that he may confound the wise. And God has chosen the weak of the world, so that he may confound the strong.
verses.textLa: sed quæ stulta sunt mundi elegit Deus, ut confundat sapientes: et infirma mundi elegit Deus, ut confundat fortia:

verses.textEn: And God has chosen the ignoble and contemptible of the world, those who are nothing, so that he may reduce to nothing those who are something.
verses.textLa: et ignobilia mundi, et contemptibilia elegit Deus, et ea, quæ non sunt, ut ea quæ sunt destrueret:

verses.textEn: So then, nothing that is of the flesh should glory in his sight.
verses.textLa: ut non glorietur omnis caro in conspectu eius.

verses.textEn: But you are of him in Christ Jesus, who was made by God to be our wisdom and justice and sanctification and redemption.
verses.textLa: Ex ipso autem vos estis in Christo Iesu, qui factus est nobis sapientia a Deo, et iustitia, et sanctificatio, et redemptio:

verses.textEn: And so, in the same way, it was written: “Whoever glories, should glory in the Lord.”
verses.textLa: ut quemadmodum scriptum est: Qui gloriatur, in Domino glorietur.

verses.textEn: And so, brothers, when I came to you, announcing to you the testimony of Christ, I did not bring exalted words or lofty wisdom.
verses.textLa: Et ego, cum venissem ad vos, fratres, veni non in sublimitate sermonis, aut sapientiæ, annuncians vobis testimonium Christi.

verses.textEn: For I did not judge myself to know anything among you, except Jesus Christ, and him crucified.
verses.textLa: Non enim iudicavi me scire aliquid inter vos, nisi Iesum Christum, et hunc crucifixum.

verses.textEn: And I was with you in weakness, and in fear, and with much trembling.
verses.textLa: Et ego in infirmitate, et timore, et tremore multo fui apud vos:

verses.textEn: And my words and preaching were not the persuasive words of human wisdom, but were a manifestation of the Spirit and of virtue,
verses.textLa: et sermo meus, et prædicatio mea non in persuasibilibus humanæ sapientiæ verbis, sed in ostensione Spiritus, et virtutis:

verses.textEn: so that your faith would not be based on the wisdom of men, but on the virtue of God.
verses.textLa: ut fides vestra non sit in sapientia hominum, sed in virtute Dei.

verses.textEn: Now, we do speak wisdom among the perfect, yet truly, this is not the wisdom of this age, nor that of the leaders of this age, which shall be reduced to nothing.
verses.textLa: Sapientiam autem loquimur inter perfectos: sapientiam vero non huius sæculi, neque principum huius sæculi, qui destruuntur:

verses.textEn: Instead, we speak of the wisdom of God in a mystery which has been hidden, which God predestined before this age for our glory,
verses.textLa: sed loquimur Dei sapientiam in mysterio, quæ abscondita est, quam prædestinavit Deus ante sæcula in gloriam nostram,

verses.textEn: something that none of the leaders of this world have known. For if they had known it, they would never have crucified the Lord of glory.
verses.textLa: quam nemo principum huius sæculi cognovit: si enim cognovissent, numquam Dominum gloriæ crucifixissent.

verses.textEn: But this is just as it has been written: “The eye has not seen, and the ear has not heard, nor has it entered into the heart of man, what things God has prepared for those who love him.”
verses.textLa: Sed sicut scriptum est: Quod oculus non vidit, nec auris audivit, nec in cor hominis ascendit, quæ præparavit Deus iis, qui diligunt illum:

verses.textEn: But God has revealed these things to us through his Spirit. For the Spirit searches all things, even the depths of God.
verses.textLa: nobis autem revelavit Deus per Spiritum suum: Spiritus enim omnia scrutatur, etiam profunda Dei.

verses.textEn: And who can know the things that are of a man, except the spirit which is within that man? So also, no one knows the things which are of God, except the Spirit of God.
verses.textLa: Quis enim hominum scit quæ sunt hominis, nisi spiritus hominis, qui in ipso est? ita et quæ Dei sunt, nemo cognovit, nisi Spiritus Dei.

verses.textEn: But we have not received the spirit of this world, but the Spirit who is of God, so that we may understand the things that have been given to us by God.
verses.textLa: Nos autem non spiritum huius mundi accepimus, sed Spiritum, qui ex Deo est, ut sciamus quæ a Deo donata sunt nobis:

verses.textEn: And we are also speaking of these things, not in the learned words of human wisdom, but in the doctrine of the Spirit, bringing spiritual things together with spiritual things.
verses.textLa: quæ et loquimur non in doctis humanæ sapientiæ verbis, sed in doctrina Spiritus, spiritualibus spiritualia comparantes.

verses.textEn: But the animal nature of man does not perceive these things that are of the Spirit of God. For it is foolishness to him, and he is not able to understand it, because it must be examined spiritually.
verses.textLa: Animalis autem homo non percipit ea, quæ sunt Spiritus Dei: stultitia enim est illi, et non potest intelligere: quia spiritualiter examinatur.

verses.textEn: But the spiritual nature of man judges all things, and he himself may be judged by no man.
verses.textLa: Spiritualis autem iudicat omnia: et ipse a nemine iudicatur.

verses.textEn: For who has known the mind of the Lord, so that he may instruct him? But we have the mind of Christ.
verses.textLa: Quis enim cognovit sensum Domini, qui instruat eum? Nos autem sensum Christi habemus.

verses.textEn: And so, brothers, I was not able to speak to you as if to those who are spiritual, but rather as if to those who are carnal. For you are like infants in Christ.
verses.textLa: Et ego, fratres, non potui vobis loqui quasi spiritualibus, sed quasi carnalibus. Tamquam parvulis in Christo,

verses.textEn: I gave you milk to drink, not solid food. For you were not yet able. And indeed, even now, you are not able; for you are still carnal.
verses.textLa: lac vobis potum dedi, non escam: nondum enim poteratis: sed nec nunc quidem potestis: adhuc enim carnales estis.

verses.textEn: And since there is still envy and contention among you, are you not carnal, and are you not walking according to man?
verses.textLa: Cum enim sit inter vos zelus, et contentio: nonne carnales estis, et secundum hominem ambulatis?

verses.textEn: For if one says, “Certainly, I am of Paul,” while another says, “I am of Apollo,” are you not men? But what is Apollo, and what is Paul?
verses.textLa: Cum enim quis dicat: Ego quidem sum Pauli. Alius autem: Ego Apollo: nonne homines estis? Quid igitur est Apollo? quid vero Paulus?

verses.textEn: We are only the ministers of him in whom you have believed, just as the Lord has granted to each of you.
verses.textLa: Ministri eius, cui credidistis, ut unicuique sicut Dominus dedit.

verses.textEn: I planted, Apollo watered, but God provided the growth.
verses.textLa: Ego plantavi, Apollo rigavit: sed Deus incrementum dedit.

verses.textEn: And so, neither he who plants, nor he who waters, is anything, but only God, who provides the growth.
verses.textLa: Itaque neque qui plantat est aliquid, neque qui rigat: sed, qui incrementum dat, Deus.

verses.textEn: Now he who plants, and he who waters, are one. But each shall receive his proper reward, according to his labors.
verses.textLa: Qui autem plantat, et qui rigat, unum sunt. Unusquisque autem propriam mercedem accipiet secundum suum laborem.

verses.textEn: For we are God’s assistants. You are God’s cultivation; you are God’s construction.
verses.textLa: Dei enim sumus adiutores: Dei agricultura estis, Dei ædificatio estis.

verses.textEn: According to the grace of God, which has been given to me, I have laid the foundation like a wise architect. But another builds upon it. So then, let each one be careful how he builds upon it.
verses.textLa: Secundum gratiam Dei, quæ data est mihi, ut sapiens architectus fundamentum posui: alius autem superædificat. Unusquisque autem videat quomodo superædificet.

verses.textEn: For no one is able to lay any other foundation, in place of that which has been laid, which is Christ Jesus.
verses.textLa: Fundamentum enim aliud nemo potest ponere præter id, quod positum est, quod est Christus Iesus.

verses.textEn: But if anyone builds upon this foundation, whether gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, or stubble,
verses.textLa: Si quis autem superædificat super fundamentum hoc, aurum, argentum, lapides pretiosos, ligna, fœnum, stipulam,

verses.textEn: each one’s work shall be made manifest. For the day of the Lord shall declare it, because it will be revealed by fire. And this fire will test each one’s work, as to what kind it is.
verses.textLa: uniuscuiusque opus manifestum erit: dies enim Domini declarabit, quia in igne revelabitur: et uniuscuiusque opus quale sit, ignis probabit.

verses.textEn: If anyone’s work, which he has built upon it, remains, then he will receive a reward.
verses.textLa: Si cuius opus manserit quod superædificavit, mercedem accipiet.

verses.textEn: If anyone’s work is burned up, he will suffer its loss, but he himself will still be saved, but only as through fire.
verses.textLa: Si cuius opus arserit, detrimentum patietur: ipse autem salvus erit: sic tamen quasi per ignem.

verses.textEn: Do you not know that you are the Temple of God, and that the Spirit of God lives within you?
verses.textLa: Nescitis quia templum Dei estis, et Spiritus Dei habitat in vobis?

verses.textEn: But if anyone violates the Temple of God, God will destroy him. For the Temple of God is holy, and you are that Temple.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem templum Dei violaverit, disperdet illum Deus. Templum enim Dei sanctum est, quod estis vos.

verses.textEn: Let no one deceive himself. If anyone among you seems to be wise in this age, let him become foolish, so that he may be truly wise.
verses.textLa: Nemo se seducat: Si quis videtur inter vos sapiens esse in hoc sæculo, stultus fiat ut sit sapiens.

verses.textEn: For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God. And so it has been written: “I will catch the wise in their own astuteness.”
verses.textLa: Sapientia enim huius mundi, stultitia est apud Deum. Scriptum est enim: Comprehendam sapientes in astutia eorum.

verses.textEn: And again: “The Lord knows the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain.”
verses.textLa: Et iterum: Dominus novit cogitationes sapientium quoniam vanæ sunt.

verses.textEn: And so, let no one glory in men.
verses.textLa: Nemo itaque glorietur in hominibus.

verses.textEn: For all is yours: whether Paul, or Apollo, or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or the present, or the future. Yes, all is yours.
verses.textLa: Omnia enim vestra sunt, sive Paulus, sive Apollo, sive Cephas, sive mundus, sive vita, sive mors, sive præsentia, sive futura: omnia enim vestra sunt:

verses.textEn: But you are Christ’s, and Christ is God’s.
verses.textLa: vos autem Christi: Christus autem Dei.

verses.textEn: Accordingly, let man consider us to be ministers of Christ and attendants of the mysteries of God.
verses.textLa: Sic nos existimet homo ut ministros Christi: et dispensatores mysteriorum Dei.

verses.textEn: Here and now, it is required of attendants that each one be found to be faithful.
verses.textLa: Hic iam quæritur inter dispensatores ut fidelis quis inveniatur.

verses.textEn: But as for me, it is such a small thing to be judged by you, or by the age of mankind. And neither do I judge myself.
verses.textLa: Mihi autem pro minimo est ut a vobis iudicer, aut ab humano die: sed neque meipsum iudico.

verses.textEn: For I have nothing on my conscience. But I am not justified by this. For the Lord is the One who judges me.
verses.textLa: Nihil enim mihi conscius sum: sed non in hoc iustificatus sum: qui autem iudicat me, Dominus est.

verses.textEn: And so, do not choose to judge before the time, until the Lord returns. He will illuminate the hidden things of the darkness, and he will make manifest the decisions of hearts. And then each one shall have praise from God.
verses.textLa: Itaque nolite ante tempus iudicare, quoadusque veniat Dominus: qui et illuminabit abscondita tenebrarum, et manifestabit consilia cordium: et tunc laus erit unicuique a Deo.

verses.textEn: And so, brothers, I have presented these things in myself and in Apollo, for your sakes, so that you may learn, through us, that no one should be inflated against one person and for another, not beyond what has been written.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem, fratres, transfiguravi in me et Apollo, propter vos: ut in nobis discatis, ne supra quam scriptum est, unus adversus alterum infletur pro alio.

verses.textEn: For what distinguishes you from another? And what do you have that you have not received? But if you have received it, why do you glory, as if you had not received it?
verses.textLa: Quis enim te discernit? Quid autem habes quod non accepisti? Si autem accepisti, quid gloriaris quasi non acceperis?

verses.textEn: So, now you have been filled, and now you have been made wealthy, as if to reign without us? But I wish that you would reign, so that we, too, might reign with you!
verses.textLa: Iam saturati estis, iam divites facti estis: sine nobis regnatis: et utinam regnetis, ut et nos vobiscum regnemus.

verses.textEn: For I think that God has presented us as the last Apostles, as those destined for death. For we have been made into a spectacle for the world, and for Angels, and for men.
verses.textLa: Puto enim quod Deus nos Apostolos novissimos ostendit, tamquam morti destinatos: quia spectaculum facti sumus mundo, et Angelis, et hominibus.

verses.textEn: So we are fools because of Christ, but you are discerning in Christ? We are weak, but you are strong? You are noble, but we are ignoble?
verses.textLa: Nos stulti propter Christum, vos autem prudentes in Christo: nos infirmi, vos autem fortes: vos nobiles, nos autem ignobiles.
verses.notes: As also in verse 4:8, Paul is being sarcastic, because some who were mere infants in the Faith have acted as if they were teachers and leaders, even above true Apostles. Such is still the case today, where those who barely know the faith exalt themselves as if teachers and leaders.

verses.textEn: Even to this very hour, we hunger and thirst, and we are naked and repeatedly beaten, and we are unsteady.
verses.textLa: Usque in hanc horam et esurimus, et sitimus, et nudi sumus, et colaphis cædimur, et instabiles sumus,

verses.textEn: And we labor, working with our own hands. We are slandered, and so we bless. We suffer and endure persecution.
verses.textLa: et laboramus operantes manibus nostris: maledicimur, et benedicimus: persecutionem patimur, et sustinemus:

verses.textEn: We are cursed, and so we pray. We have become like the refuse of this world, like the reside of everything, even until now.
verses.textLa: blasphemamur, et obsecramus: tamquam purgamenta huius mundi facti sumus, omnium peripsema usque adhuc.

verses.textEn: I am not writing these things in order to confound you, but in order to admonish you, as my dearest sons.
verses.textLa: Non ut confundam vos, hæc scribo, sed ut filios meos charissimos moneo.

verses.textEn: For you might have ten thousand instructors in Christ, but not so many fathers. For in Christ Jesus, through the Gospel, I have begotten you.
verses.textLa: Nam si decem millia pædagogorum habeatis in Christo: sed non multos patres. Nam in Christo Iesu per Evangelium ego vos genui.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I beg you, be imitators of me, just as I am of Christ.
verses.textLa: Rogo ergo vos, imitatores mei estote, sicut et ego Christi.

verses.textEn: For this reason, I have sent you Timothy, who is my dearest son, and who is faithful in the Lord. He will remind you of my ways, which are in Christ Jesus, just as I teach everywhere, in every church.
verses.textLa: Ideo misi ad vos Timotheum, qui est filius meus charissimus, et fidelis in Domino: qui vos commonefaciet vias meas, quæ sunt in Christo Iesu, sicut ubique in omni Ecclesia doceo.

verses.textEn: Certain persons have become inflated in thinking that I would not return to you.
verses.textLa: Tamquam non venturus sim ad vos, sic inflati sunt quidam.

verses.textEn: But I will return to you soon, if the Lord is willing. And I will consider, not the words of those who are inflated, but the virtue.
verses.textLa: Veniam autem ad vos cito, si Dominus voluerit: et cognoscam non sermonem eorum, qui inflati sunt, sed virtutem.

verses.textEn: For the kingdom of God is not in words, but in virtue.
verses.textLa: Non enim in sermone est regnum Dei, sed in virtute.

verses.textEn: What would you prefer? Should I return to you with a rod, or with charity and a spirit of meekness?
verses.textLa: Quid vultis? In virga veniam ad vos, an in charitate, et spiritu mansuetudinis?

verses.textEn: Above all else, it is being said that there is fornication among you, even fornication of a such kind that is not among the Gentiles, so that someone would have the wife of his father.
verses.textLa: Omnino auditur inter vos fornicatio, et talis fornicatio, qualis nec inter Gentes, ita ut uxorem patris sui aliquis habeat.
verses.notes: The expression ‘wife of his father’ refers to his stepmother, not his natural mother.

verses.textEn: And yet you are inflated, and you have not instead been grieved, so that he who has done this thing would be taken away from your midst.
verses.textLa: Et vos inflati estis: et non magis luctum habuistis ut tollatur de medio vestrum qui hoc opus fecit.

verses.textEn: Certainly, though absent in body, I am present in spirit. Thus, I have already judged, as if I were present, him who has done this.
verses.textLa: Ego quidem absens corpore, præsens autem spiritu, iam iudicavi ut præsens, eum, qui sic operatus est,

verses.textEn: In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, you have been gathered together with my spirit, in the power of our Lord Jesus,
verses.textLa: in nomine Domini nostri Iesu Christi, congregatis vobis et meo spiritu, cum virtute Domini nostri Iesu,

verses.textEn: to hand over such a one as this to Satan, for the destruction of the flesh, so that the spirit may be saved in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: tradere huiusmodi Satanæ in interitum carnis, ut spiritus salvus sit in die Domini nostri Iesu Christi.

verses.textEn: It is not good for you to glory. Do you not know that a little leaven corrupts the entire mass?
verses.textLa: Non est bona gloriatio vestra. Nescitis quia modicum fermentum totam massam corrumpit?

verses.textEn: Purge the old leaven, so that you may become the new bread, for you are unleavened. For Christ, our Passover, has now been immolated.
verses.textLa: Expurgate vetus fermentum, ut sitis nova conspersio, sicut estis azymi. Etenim Pascha nostrum immolatus est Christus.

verses.textEn: And so, let us feast, not with the old leaven, not with the leaven of malice and wickedness, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.
verses.textLa: Itaque epulemur: non in fermento veteri, neque in fermento malitiæ, et nequitiæ: sed in azymis sinceritatis, et veritatis.

verses.textEn: As I have written to you in an epistle: “Do not associate with fornicators,”
verses.textLa: Scripsi in epistola: Ne commisceamini fornicariis.

verses.textEn: certainly not with the fornicators of this world, nor with the greedy, nor with robbers, nor with the servants of idolatry. Otherwise, you ought to depart from this world.
verses.textLa: Non utique fornicariis huius mundi, aut avaris, aut rapacibus, aut idolis servientibus: alioquin debueratis de hoc mundo exiisse.

verses.textEn: But now I have written to you: do not associate with anyone who is called a brother and yet is a fornicator, or greedy, or a servant of idolatry, or a slanderer, or inebriated, or a robber. With such a one as this, do not even take food.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem scripsi vobis non commisceri: si is, qui frater nominatur, est fornicator, aut avarus, aut idolis serviens, aut maledicus, aut ebriosus, aut rapax: cum eiusmodi nec cibum sumere.

verses.textEn: For what have I to do with judging those who are outside? But do not even you yourselves judge those who are inside?
verses.textLa: Quid enim mihi de iis, qui foris sunt, iudicare? Nonne de iis, qui intus sunt, vos iudicatis?

verses.textEn: For those who are outside, God will judge. But send this evil person away from yourselves.
verses.textLa: Nam eos, qui foris sunt, Deus iudicabit. Auferte malum ex vobis ipsis.

verses.textEn: How is it that anyone of you, having a dispute against another, would dare to be judged before the iniquitous, and not before the saints?
verses.textLa: Audet aliquis vestrum habens negotium adversus alterum, iudicari apud iniquos, et non apud sanctos?

verses.textEn: Or do you not know that the saints from this age shall judge it? And if the world is to be judged by you, are you unworthy, then, to judge even the smallest matters?
verses.textLa: An nescitis quoniam sancti de hoc mundo iudicabunt? Et si in vobis iudicabitur mundus, indigni estis qui de minimis iudicetis?

verses.textEn: Do you not know that we shall judge angels? How much more the things of this age?
verses.textLa: Nescitis quoniam Angelos iudicabimus? Quanto magis sæcularia?

verses.textEn: Therefore, if you have matters to judge concerning this age, why not appoint those who are most contemptible in the Church to judge these things!
verses.textLa: Sæcularia igitur iudicia si habueritis: contemptibiles, qui sunt in Ecclesia, illos constituite ad iudicandum!

verses.textEn: But I am speaking so as to shame you. Is there no one among you wise enough, so that he might be able to judge between his brothers?
verses.textLa: Ad verecundiam vestram dico. Sic non est inter vos sapiens quisquam, qui possit iudicare inter fratrem suum?

verses.textEn: Instead, brother contends against brother in court, and this before the unfaithful!
verses.textLa: Sed frater cum fratre iudicio contendit: et hoc apud infideles!

verses.textEn: Now there is certainly an offense among you, beyond everything else, when you have court cases against one another. Should you not accept injury instead? Should you not endure being cheated instead?
verses.textLa: Iam quidem omnino delictum est in vobis, quod iudicia habetis inter vos. Quare non magis iniuriam accipitis? Quare non magis fraudem patimini?

verses.textEn: But you are doing the injuring and the cheating, and this toward brothers!
verses.textLa: Sed vos iniuriam facitis, et fraudatis: et hoc fratribus.

verses.textEn: Do you not know that the iniquitous will not possess the kingdom of God? Do not choose to wander astray. For neither fornicators, nor servants of idolatry, nor adulterers,
verses.textLa: An nescitis quia iniqui regnum Dei non possidebunt? Nolite errare: Neque fornicarii, neque idolis servientes, neque adulteri,

verses.textEn: nor the effeminate, nor males who sleep with males, nor thieves, nor the avaricious, nor the inebriated, nor slanderers, nor the rapacious shall possess the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: neque molles, neque masculorum concubitores, neque fures, neque avari, neque ebriosi, neque maledici, neque rapaces regnum Dei possidebunt.

verses.textEn: And some of you were like this. But you have been absolved, but you have been sanctified, but you have been justified: all in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ and in the Spirit of our God.
verses.textLa: Et hæc quidam fuistis: sed abluti estis, sed sanctificati estis, sed iustificati estis in nomine Domini nostri Iesu Christi, et in Spiritu Dei nostri.

verses.textEn: All is lawful to me, but not all is expedient. All is lawful to me, but I will not be driven back by the authority of anyone.
verses.textLa: Omnia mihi licent, sed non omnia expediunt: Omnia mihi licent, sed ego sub nullis redigar potestate.

verses.textEn: Food is for the stomach, and the stomach is for food. But God shall destroy both the stomach and food. And the body is not for fornication, but rather for the Lord; and the Lord is for the body.
verses.textLa: Esca ventri, et venter escis: Deus autem et hunc, et has destruet: corpus autem non fornicationi, sed Domino: et Dominus corpori.

verses.textEn: Truly, God has raised up the Lord, and he will raise us up by his power.
verses.textLa: Deus vero et Dominum suscitavit: et nos suscitabit per virtutem suam.

verses.textEn: Do you not know that your bodies are a part of Christ? So then, should I take a part of Christ and make it a part of a harlot? Let it not be so!
verses.textLa: Nescitis quoniam corpora vestra membra sunt Christi? Tollens ergo membra Christi, faciam membra meretricis? Absit.

verses.textEn: And do you not know that whoever is joined to a harlot becomes one body? “For the two,” he said, “shall be as one flesh.”
verses.textLa: An nescitis quoniam qui adhæret meretrici, unum corpus efficitur? Erunt enim (inquit) duo in carne una.

verses.textEn: But whoever is joined to the Lord is one spirit.
verses.textLa: Qui autem adhæret Domino, unus spiritus est.

verses.textEn: Flee from fornication. Every sin whatsoever that a man commits is outside of the body, but whoever fornicates, sins against his own body.
verses.textLa: Fugite fornicationem. Omne peccatum, quodcumque fecerit homo, extra corpus est: qui autem fornicatur, in corpus suum peccat.

verses.textEn: Or do you not know that your bodies are the Temple of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have from God, and that you are not your own?
verses.textLa: An nescitis quoniam membra vestra, templum sunt Spiritus Sancti, qui in vobis est, quem habetis a Deo, et non estis vestri?

verses.textEn: For you have been bought at a great price. Glorify and carry God in your body.
verses.textLa: Empti enim estis pretio magno. Glorificate, et portate Deum in corpore vestro.

verses.textEn: Now concerning the things about which you wrote to me: It is good for a man not to touch a woman.
verses.textLa: De quibus autem scripsistis mihi: Bonum est homini mulierem non tangere:

verses.textEn: But, because of fornication, let each man have his own wife, and let each woman have her own husband.
verses.textLa: propter fornicationem autem unusquisque suam uxorem habeat, et unaquæque suum virum habeat.

verses.textEn: A husband should fulfill his obligation to his wife, and a wife should also act similarly toward her husband.
verses.textLa: Uxori vir debitum reddat: similiter autem et uxor viro.

verses.textEn: It is not the wife, but the husband, who has power over her body. But, similarly also, it is not the husband, but the wife, who has power over his body.
verses.textLa: Mulier sui corporis potestatem non habet, sed vir. Similiter autem et vir sui corporis potestatem non habet, sed mulier.

verses.textEn: So, do not fail in your obligations to one another, except perhaps by consent, for a limited time, so that you may empty yourselves for prayer. And then, return together again, lest Satan tempt you by means of your abstinence.
verses.textLa: Nolite fraudare invicem, nisi forte ex consensu ad tempus, ut vacetis orationi: et iterum revertimini in idipsum, ne tentet vos Satanas propter incontinentiam vestram.

verses.textEn: But I am saying this, neither as an indulgence, nor as a commandment.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem dico secundum indulgentiam, non secundum imperium.

verses.textEn: For I would prefer it if you were all like myself. But each person has his proper gift from God: one in this way, yet another in that way.
verses.textLa: Volo enim omnes vos esse sicut meipsum: sed unusquisque proprium donum habet ex Deo: alius quidem sic, alius vero sic.

verses.textEn: But I say to the unmarried and to widows: It is good for them, if they would remain as they are, just as I also am.
verses.textLa: Dico autem non nuptis, et viduis: bonum est illis si sic permaneant, sicut et ego.

verses.textEn: But if they cannot restrain themselves, they should marry. For it is better to marry, than to be burned.
verses.textLa: Quod si non se continent, nubant. Melius est enim nubere, quam uri.
verses.notes: The Latin says ‘than to be burned,’ i.e. in the fires of Hell, due to sins of fornication. The Latin does not say ‘than to burn,’ i.e. to burn with desire.

verses.textEn: But to those who have been joined in matrimony, it is not I who commands you, but the Lord: a wife is not to separate from her husband.
verses.textLa: Iis autem, qui matrimonio iuncti sunt, præcipio non ego, sed Dominus, uxorem a viro non discedere:

verses.textEn: But if she has separated from him, she must remain unmarried, or be reconciled to her husband. And a husband should not divorce his wife.
verses.textLa: quod si discesserit, manere innuptam, aut viro suo reconciliari. Et vir uxorem non dimittat.

verses.textEn: Concerning the rest, I am speaking, not the Lord. If any brother has an unbelieving wife, and she consents to live with him, he should not divorce her.
verses.textLa: Nam ceteris ego dico, non Dominus. Si quis frater uxorem habet infidelem, et hæc consentit habitare cum illo, non dimittat illam.

verses.textEn: And if any woman has an unbelieving husband, and he consents to live with her, she should not divorce her husband.
verses.textLa: Et si qua mulier fidelis habet virum infidelem, et hic consentit habitare cum illa, non dimittat virum:

verses.textEn: For the unbelieving husband has been sanctified through the believing wife, and the unbelieving wife has been sanctified through the believing husband. Otherwise, your children would be unclean, whereas instead they are holy.
verses.textLa: sanctificatus est enim vir infidelis per mulierem fidelem, et sanctificata est mulier infidelis per virum fidelem: alioquin filii vestri immundi essent, nunc autem sancti sunt.

verses.textEn: But if the unbeliever departs, let him depart. For a brother or sister cannot be made subject to servitude in this way. For God has called us to peace.
verses.textLa: Quod si infidelis discedit, discedat: non enim servituti subiectus est frater, aut soror in huiusmodi: in pace autem vocavit nos Deus.

verses.textEn: And how do you know, wife, whether you will save your husband? Or how do you know, husband, whether you will save your wife?
verses.textLa: Unde enim scis mulier, si virum salvum facies? Aut unde scis vir, si mulierem salvam facies?

verses.textEn: However, let each one walk just as the Lord has distributed to him, each one just as God has called him. And thus do I teach in all the churches.
verses.textLa: Nisi unicuique sicut divisit Dominus, unumquemque sicut vocavit Deus, ita ambulet, et sicut in omnibus Ecclesiis doceo.

verses.textEn: Has any circumcised man been called? Let him not cover his circumcision. Has any uncircumcised man been called? Let him not be circumcised.
verses.textLa: Circumcisus aliquis vocatus est? Non adducat præputium. In præputio aliquis vocatus est? Non circumcidatur.

verses.textEn: Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing; there is only the observance of the commandments of God.
verses.textLa: Circumcisio nihil est, et præputium nihil est: sed observatio mandatorum Dei.

verses.textEn: Let each and every one remain in the same calling to which he was called.
verses.textLa: Unusquisque in qua vocatione vocatus est, in ea permaneat.

verses.textEn: Are you a servant who has been called? Do not be concerned about it. But if you ever have the ability to be free, make use of it.
verses.textLa: Servus vocatus es? Non sit tibi curæ: sed et si potes fieri liber, magis utere.

verses.textEn: For any servant who has been called in the Lord is free in the Lord. Similarly, any free person who has been called is a servant in Christ.
verses.textLa: Qui enim in Domino vocatus est servus, libertus est Domini: similiter qui liber vocatus est, servus est Christi.

verses.textEn: You have been bought with a price. Do not be willing to become the servants of men.
verses.textLa: Pretio empti estis, nolite fieri servi hominum.

verses.textEn: Brothers, let each one, in whatever state he was called, remain in that state with God.
verses.textLa: Unusquisque in quo vocatus est, fratres, in hoc permaneat apud Deum.

verses.textEn: Now, concerning virgins, I have no commandment from the Lord. But I give counsel, as one who has obtained the mercy of the Lord, so as to be faithful.
verses.textLa: De virginibus autem præceptum Domini non habeo: consilium autem do, tamquam misericordiam consecutus a Domino, ut sim fidelis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I consider this to be good, because of the present necessity: that it is good for a man to be such as I am.
verses.textLa: Existimo ergo hoc bonum esse propter instantem necessitatem, quoniam bonum est homini sic esse.

verses.textEn: Are you bound to a wife? Do not seek to be freed. Are you free of a wife? Do not seek a wife.
verses.textLa: Alligatus es uxori? Noli quærere solutionem. Solutus es ab uxore? Noli quærere uxorem.

verses.textEn: But if you take a wife, you have not sinned. And if a virgin has married, she has not sinned. Even so, such as these will have the tribulation of the flesh. But I would spare you from this.
verses.textLa: Si autem acceperis uxorem: non peccasti. Et si nupserit virgo, non peccavit. Tribulationem tamen carnis habebunt huiusmodi. Ego autem vobis parco.

verses.textEn: And so, this is what I say, brothers: The time is short. What remains of it is such that: those who have wives should be as if they had none;
verses.textLa: Hoc itaque dico, fratres: Tempus breve est: reliquum est, ut et qui habent uxores, tamquam non habentes sint:

verses.textEn: and those who weep, as though they were not weeping; and those who rejoice, as if they were not rejoicing; and those who buy, as if they possessed nothing;
verses.textLa: et qui flent, tamquam non flentes: et qui gaudent, tamquam non gaudentes: et qui emunt, tamquam non possidentes:

verses.textEn: and those who use the things of this world, as if they were not using them. For the figure of this world is passing away.
verses.textLa: et qui utuntur hoc mundo, tamquam non utantur: præterit enim figura huius mundi.

verses.textEn: But I would prefer you to be without worry. Whoever is without a wife is worried about the things of the Lord, as to how he may please God.
verses.textLa: Volo autem vos sine solicitudine esse. Qui sine uxore est, solicitus est quæ Domini sunt, quomodo placeat Deo.

verses.textEn: But whoever is with a wife is worried about the things of the world, as to how he may please his wife. And so, he is divided.
verses.textLa: Qui autem cum uxore est, solicitus est quæ sunt mundi, quomodo placeat uxori, et divisus est.

verses.textEn: And the unmarried woman and the virgin think about the things that are of the Lord, so that she may be holy in body and in spirit. But she who is married thinks about the things that are of the world, as to how she may please her husband.
verses.textLa: Et mulier innupta, et virgo cogitat quæ Domini sunt, ut sit sancta corpore, et spiritu. Quæ autem nupta est, cogitat quæ sunt mundi, quomodo placeat viro.

verses.textEn: Furthermore, I am saying this for your own benefit, not in order to cast a snare over you, but toward whatever is honest and whatever may provide you with the ability to be without hindrance, so as to worship the Lord.
verses.textLa: Porro hoc ad utilitatem vestram dico: non ut laqueum vobis iniiciam, sed ad id, quod honestum est, et quod facultatem præbeat sine impedimento Dominum obsecrandi.

verses.textEn: But if any man considers himself to seem dishonorable, concerning a virgin who is of adult age, and so it ought to be, he may do as he wills. If he marries her, he does not sin.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem turpem se videri existimat super virgine sua, quod sit superadulta, et ita oportet fieri: quod vult faciat: non peccat, si nubat.

verses.textEn: But if he has decided firmly in his heart, and he does not have any obligation, but only the power of his free will, and if he has judged this in his heart, to let her remain a virgin, he does well.
verses.textLa: Nam qui statuit in corde suo firmus, non habens necessitatem, potestatem autem habens suæ voluntatis, et hoc iudicavit in corde suo, servare virginem suam, bene facit.

verses.textEn: And so, he who joins with his virgin in matrimony does well, and he who does not join with her does better.
verses.textLa: Igitur et qui matrimonio iungit virginem suam, bene facit: et qui non iungit, melius facit.

verses.textEn: A woman is bound under the law for as long as her husband lives. But if her husband has died, she is free. She may marry whomever she wishes, but only in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Mulier alligata est legi quanto tempore vir eius vivit. Quod si dormierit vir eius, liberata est: cui vult nubat: tantum in Domino.

verses.textEn: But she will be more blessed, if she remains in this state, in accord with my counsel. And I think that I, too, have the Spirit of God.
verses.textLa: Beatior autem erit si sic permanserit secundum meum consilium: puto autem quod et ego Spiritum Dei habeam.

verses.textEn: Now concerning those things that are sacrificed to idols: we know that we all have knowledge. Knowledge puffs up, but charity builds up.
verses.textLa: De iis autem, quæ idolis sacrificantur, scimus quia omnes scientiam habemus. Scientia inflat, charitas vero ædificat.

verses.textEn: But if anyone considers himself to know anything, he does not yet know in the way that he ought to know.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem se existimat scire aliquid, nondum cognovit quemadmodum oporteat eum scire.

verses.textEn: For if anyone loves God, he is known by him.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem diligit Deum, hic cognitus est ab eo.

verses.textEn: But as to the foods that are immolated to idols, we know that an idol in the world is nothing, and that no one is God, except One.
verses.textLa: De escis autem, quæ idolis immolantur, scimus quia nihil est idolum in mundo, et quod nullus est Deus, nisi unus.

verses.textEn: For although there are things that are called gods, whether in heaven or on earth, (if one even considers there to be many gods and many lords)
verses.textLa: Nam etsi sunt qui dicantur dii sive in cælo, sive in terra (si quidem sunt dii multi, et domini multi):

verses.textEn: yet we know that there is only one God, the Father, from whom all things are, and in whom we are, and one Lord Jesus Christ, through whom all things are, and by whom we are.
verses.textLa: nobis tamen unus est Deus, Pater, ex quo omnia, et nos in illum: et unus Dominus Iesus Christus, per quem omnia, et nos per ipsum.

verses.textEn: But knowledge is not in everyone. For some persons, even now, with consent to an idol, eat what has been sacrificed to an idol. And their conscience, being infirm, becomes polluted.
verses.textLa: Sed non in omnibus est scientia. Quidam autem cum conscientia usque nunc idoli, quasi idolothytum manducant: et conscientia ipsorum cum sit infirma, polluitur.

verses.textEn: Yet food does not commend us to God. For if we eat, we will not have more, and if we do not eat, we will not have less.
verses.textLa: Esca autem nos non commendat Deo. Neque enim si manducaverimus, abundabimus: neque si non manducaverimus, deficiemus.

verses.textEn: But be careful not to let your liberty become a cause of sin to those who are weak.
verses.textLa: Videte autem ne forte hæc licentia vestra offendiculum fiat infirmis.

verses.textEn: For if anyone sees someone with knowledge sitting down to eat in idolatry, will not his own conscience, being infirm, be emboldened to eat what has been sacrificed to idols?
verses.textLa: Si enim quis viderit eum, qui habet scientiam, in idolio recumbentem: nonne conscientia eius, cum sit infirma, ædificabitur ad manducandum idolothyta?

verses.textEn: And should an infirm brother perish by your knowledge, even though Christ died for him?
verses.textLa: Et peribit infirmus in tua scientia frater, propter quem Christus mortuus est?

verses.textEn: So when you sin in this way against the brothers, and you harm their weakened conscience, then you sin against Christ.
verses.textLa: Sic autem peccantes in fratres, et percutientes conscientiam eorum infirmam, in Christum peccatis.

verses.textEn: Because of this, if food leads my brother to sin, I will never eat meat, lest I lead my brother to sin.
verses.textLa: Quapropter si esca scandalizat fratrem meum: non manducabo carnem in æternum, ne fratrem meum scandalizem.

verses.textEn: Am I not free? Am I not an Apostle? Have I not seen Christ Jesus our Lord? Are you not my work in the Lord?
verses.textLa: Non sum liber? Non sum Apostolus? Nonne Christum Iesum Dominum nostrum vidi? Nonne opus meum vos estis in Domino?

verses.textEn: And if I am not an Apostle to others, yet still I am to you. For you are the seal of my Apostleship in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et si aliis non sum Apostolus, sed tamen vobis sum: nam signaculum Apostolatus mei vos estis in Domino.

verses.textEn: My defense with those who question me is this:
verses.textLa: Mea defensio apud eos, qui me interrogant, hæc est:

verses.textEn: Do we not have the authority to eat and to drink?
verses.textLa: Numquid non habemus potestatem manducandi, et bibendi?

verses.textEn: Do we not have the authority to travel around with a woman who is a sister, just as do the other Apostles, and the brothers of the Lord, and Cephas?
verses.textLa: Numquid non habemus potestatem mulierem sororem circumducendi sicut et ceteri Apostoli, et fratres Domini, et Cephas?

verses.textEn: Or is it only myself and Barnabas who do not have the authority to act in this way?
verses.textLa: Aut ego solus, et Barnabas, non habemus potestatem hoc operandi?

verses.textEn: Who has ever served as a soldier and paid his own stipend? Who plants a vineyard and does not eat from its produce? Who pastures a flock and does not drink from the milk of the flock?
verses.textLa: Quis militat suis stipendiis umquam? Quis plantat vineam, et de fructu eius non edit? Quis pascit gregem, et de lacte gregis non manducat?

verses.textEn: Am I saying these things according to man? Or does the law not also say these things?
verses.textLa: Numquid secundum hominem hæc dico? An et lex hæc non dicit?

verses.textEn: For it is written in the law of Moses: “You shall not bind the mouth of an ox, while it is treading out the grain.” Is God here concerned with the oxen?
verses.textLa: Scriptum est enim in lege Moysi: Non alligabis os bovi trituranti. Numquid de bobus cura est Deo?

verses.textEn: Or is he saying this, indeed, for our sake? These things were written specifically for us, because he who plows, ought to plow in hope, and he who threshes, too, in hope of receiving the produce.
verses.textLa: An propter nos utique hoc dicit? Nam propter nos scripta sunt, quoniam debet in spe qui arat, arare: et qui triturat, in spe fructus percipiendi.

verses.textEn: If we have sown spiritual things in you, is it important if we harvest from your worldly things?
verses.textLa: Si nos vobis spiritualia seminavimus, magnum est si nos carnalia vestra metamus?

verses.textEn: If others are sharers in this authority over you, why are we not more entitled? And yet we have not used this authority. Instead, we bear all things, lest we give any hindrance to the Gospel of Christ.
verses.textLa: Si alii potestatis vestræ participes sunt, quare non potius nos? Sed non usi sumus hac potestate: sed omnia sustinemus, ne quod offendiculum demus Evangelio Christi.

verses.textEn: Do you not know that those who work in the holy place eat the things that are for the holy place, and that those who serve at the altar also share with the altar?
verses.textLa: Nescitis quoniam qui in sacrario operantur, quæ de sacrario sunt, edunt: et qui altari deserviunt, cum altari participant?

verses.textEn: So, too, has the Lord ordained that those who announce the Gospel should live by the Gospel.
verses.textLa: Ita et Dominus ordinavit iis, qui Evangelium annunciant, de Evangelio vivere.

verses.textEn: Yet I have used none of these things. And I have not written so that these things may be done for me. For it is better for me to die, rather than to let anyone empty out my glory.
verses.textLa: Ego autem nullo horum usus sum. Non autem scripsi hæc ut ita fiant in me: bonum est enim mihi magis mori, quam ut gloriam meam quis evacuet.

verses.textEn: For if I preach the Gospel, it is not glory for me. For an obligation has been laid upon me. And woe to me, if I do not preach the Gospel.
verses.textLa: Nam si evangelizavero, non est mihi gloria: necessitas enim mihi incumbit: væ enim mihi est, si non evangelizavero.

verses.textEn: For if I do this willingly, I have a reward. But if I do this reluctantly, a dispensation is granted to me.
verses.textLa: Si enim volens hoc ago, mercedem habeo: si autem invitus, dispensatio mihi credita est.

verses.textEn: And what, then, would be my reward? So, when preaching the Gospel, I should give the Gospel without taking, so that I may not misuse my authority in the Gospel.
verses.textLa: Quæ est ergo merces mea? Ut Evangelium prædicans, sine sumptu ponam Evangelium, ut non abutar potestate mea in Evangelio.

verses.textEn: For when I was a free man to all, I made myself the servant of all, so that I might gain all the more.
verses.textLa: Nam cum liber essem ex omnibus, omnium me servum feci, ut plures lucrifacerem.

verses.textEn: And so, to the Jews, I became like a Jew, so that I might gain the Jews.
verses.textLa: Et factus sum Iudæis tamquam Iudæus, ut Iudæos lucrarer.

verses.textEn: To those who are under the law, I became as if I were under the law, (though I was not under the law) so that I might gain those who were under the law. To those who were without the law, I became as if I were without the law, (though I was not without the law of God, being in the law of Christ) so that I might gain those who were without the law.
verses.textLa: Iis qui sub lege sunt, quasi sub lege essem (cum ipse non essem sub lege) ut eos, qui sub lege erant, lucrifacerem. Iis, qui sine lege erant, tamquam sine lege essem (cum sine lege Dei non essem: sed in lege essem Christi) ut lucrifacerem eos, qui sine lege erant.

verses.textEn: To the weak, I became weak, so that I might gain the weak. To all, I became all, so that I might save all.
verses.textLa: Factus sum infirmis infirmus, ut infirmos lucrifacerem. Omnibus omnia factus sum, ut omnes facerem salvos.

verses.textEn: And I do everything for the sake of the Gospel, so that I may become its partner.
verses.textLa: Omnia autem facio propter Evangelium: ut particeps eius efficiar.

verses.textEn: Do you not know that, of those who run in a race, all of them, certainly, are runners, but only one achieves the prize. Similarly, you must run, so that you may achieve.
verses.textLa: Nescitis quod ii, qui in stadio currunt, omnes quidem currunt, sed unus accipit bravium? Sic currite ut comprehendatis.

verses.textEn: And one who competes in a contest abstains from all things. And they do this, of course, so that they may achieve a corruptible crown. But we do this, so that we may achieve what is incorruptible.
verses.textLa: Omnis autem, qui in agone contendit, ab omnibus se abstinet: et illi quidem ut corruptibilem coronam accipiant: nos autem incorruptam.

verses.textEn: And so I run, but not with uncertainty. And so I fight, but not by flailing in the air.
verses.textLa: Ego igitur sic curro, non quasi in incertum: sic pugno, non quasi aerem verberans:

verses.textEn: Instead, I chastise my body, so as to redirect it into servitude. Otherwise, I might preach to others, but become myself an outcast.
verses.textLa: sed castigo corpus meum, et in servitutem redigo: ne forte cum aliis prædicaverim, ipse reprobus efficiar.

verses.textEn: For I do not want you to be ignorant, brothers, that our fathers were all under the cloud, and they all went across the sea.
verses.textLa: Nolo enim vos ignorare fratres quoniam patres nostri omnes sub nube fuerunt, et omnes mare transierunt,

verses.textEn: And in Moses, they all were baptized, in the cloud and in the sea.
verses.textLa: et omnes in Moyse baptizati sunt in nube, et in mari:

verses.textEn: And they all ate of the same spiritual food.
verses.textLa: et omnes eandem escam spiritalem manducaverunt,

verses.textEn: And they all drank of the same spiritual drink. And so, they all were drinking of the spiritual rock seeking to obtain them; and that rock was Christ.
verses.textLa: et omnes eundem potum spiritalem biberunt: bibebant autem de spiritali, consequente eos, petra: petra autem erat Christus.

verses.textEn: But with most of them, God was not well-pleased. For they were struck down in the desert.
verses.textLa: Sed non in pluribus eorum beneplacitum est Deo: nam prostrati sunt in deserto.
verses.notes: They lay prostrate in the desert, in other words, their dead bodies lay in the desert.

verses.textEn: Now these things were done as an example for us, so that we might not desire evil things, just as they desired.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem in figura facta sunt nostri, ut non simus concupiscentes malorum, sicut et illi concupierunt.

verses.textEn: And so, do not take part in idolatry, as some of them did, just as it was written: “The people sat down to eat and to drink, and then they rose up to amuse themselves.”
verses.textLa: Neque idololatræ efficiamini, sicut quidam ex ipsis: quemadmodum scriptum est: Sedit populus manducare, et bibere, et surrexerunt ludere.

verses.textEn: And let us not commit fornication, as some of them fornicated, and so twenty-three thousand fell on one day.
verses.textLa: Neque fornicemur, sicut quidam ex ipsis fornicati sunt, et ceciderunt una die viginti tria millia.

verses.textEn: And let us not tempt Christ, as some of them tempted, and so they perished by serpents.
verses.textLa: Neque tentemus Christum: sicut quidam eorum tentaverunt, et a serpentibus perierunt.

verses.textEn: And you should not murmur, as some of them murmured, and so they perished by the destroyer.
verses.textLa: Neque murmuraveritis, sicut quidam eorum murmuraverunt, et perierunt ab exterminatore.

verses.textEn: Now all of these things happened to them as an example, and so they have been written for our correction, because the final age has fallen upon us.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem omnia in figura contingebant illis: scripta sunt autem ad correptionem nostram, in quos fines sæculorum devenerunt.

verses.textEn: And so, whosoever considers himself to be standing, let him be careful not to fall.
verses.textLa: Itaque qui se existimat stare, videat ne cadat.

verses.textEn: Temptation should not take hold of you, except what is human. For God is faithful, and he will not permit you to be tempted beyond your ability. Instead, he will effect his Providence, even during temptation, so that you may be able to bear it.
verses.textLa: Tentatio vos non apprehendat nisi humana: fidelis autem Deus est, qui non patietur vos tentari supra id, quod potestis, sed faciet etiam cum tentatione proventum ut possitis sustinere.
verses.notes: The word ‘proventum’ is not so much a way out, but the result of events, especially a successful outcome. When God accomplishes such an outcome, it is called Providence. Thus, the phrase ‘effect his providence’ is used, instead of the more literal ‘cause an outcome’ or ‘accomplish a good result.’

verses.textEn: Because of this, most beloved of mine, flee from the worship of idols.
verses.textLa: Propter quod charissimi mihi, fugite ab idolorum cultura:

verses.textEn: Since I am speaking to those who are prudent, judge what I say for yourselves.
verses.textLa: Ut prudentibus loquor, vos ipsi iudicate quod dico.

verses.textEn: The cup of benediction that we bless, is it not a communion in the Blood of Christ? And the bread that we break, is it not a participation in the Body of the Lord?
verses.textLa: Calix benedictionis, cui benedicimus, nonne communicatio sanguinis Christi est? Et panis, quem frangimus, nonne participatio corporis Domini est?

verses.textEn: Through the one bread, we, though many, are one body: all of us who are partakers of the one bread.
verses.textLa: Quoniam unus panis, unum corpus multi sumus, omnes, qui de uno pane participamus.

verses.textEn: Consider Israel, according to the flesh. Are not those who eat from the sacrifices partakers of the altar?
verses.textLa: Videte Israel secundum carnem: nonne qui edunt hostias, participes sunt altaris?

verses.textEn: What is next? Should I say that what is immolated to idols is anything? Or that the idol is anything?
verses.textLa: Quid ergo? Dico quod idolis immolatum sit aliquid? Aut quod idolum, sit aliquid?

verses.textEn: But the things that the Gentiles immolate, they immolate to demons, and not to God. And I do not want you to become partakers with demons.
verses.textLa: Sed quæ immolant Gentes, dæmoniis immolant, et non Deo. Nolo autem vos socios fieri dæmoniorum:
verses.notes: This verse and its idea are a foreshadowing of the abomination of desolation, a perverse imitation of the holy Eucharist, which is done in cooperation with fallen angels.

verses.textEn: You cannot drink the cup of the Lord, and the cup of demons. You cannot be partakers of the table of the Lord, and partakers of the table of demons.
verses.textLa: non potestis calicem Domini bibere, et calicem dæmoniorum: non potestis mensæ Domini participes esse, et mensæ dæmoniorum.

verses.textEn: Or should we provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than he is? All is lawful to me, but not all is expedient.
verses.textLa: An æmulamur Dominum? Numquid fortiores illo sumus? Omnia mihi licent, sed non omnia expediunt.

verses.textEn: All is lawful to me, but not all is edifying.
verses.textLa: Omnia mihi licent, sed non omnia ædificat.

verses.textEn: Let no one seek for himself, but for others.
verses.textLa: Nemo quod suum est quærat, sed quod alterius.

verses.textEn: Whatever is sold in the market, you may eat, without asking questions for the sake of conscience.
verses.textLa: Omne, quod in macello vænit, manducate, nihil interrogantes propter conscientiam.

verses.textEn: “The earth and all its fullness belong to the Lord.”
verses.textLa: Domini est terra, et plenitudo eius.

verses.textEn: If you are invited by any unbelievers, and you are willing to go, you may eat whatever is set before you, without asking questions for the sake of conscience.
verses.textLa: Si quis vocat vos infidelium, et vultis ire: omne, quod vobis apponitur, manducate, nihil interrogantes propter conscientiam.

verses.textEn: But if anyone says, “This has been sacrificed to idols,” do not eat it, for the sake of the one who told you, and for the sake of conscience.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem dixerit: Hoc immolatum est idolis: nolite manducare propter illum, qui indicavit, et propter conscientiam:

verses.textEn: But I am referring to the conscience of the other person, not to yours. For why should my liberty be judged by the conscience of another?
verses.textLa: conscientiam autem dico non tuam, sed alterius. Ut quid enim libertas mea iudicatur ab aliena conscientia?

verses.textEn: If I partake with thanksgiving, why should I be slandered over that for which I give thanks?
verses.textLa: Si ego cum gratia participo, quid blasphemor pro eo quod gratias ago?

verses.textEn: Therefore, whether you eat or drink, or whatever else you may do, do everything for the glory of God.
verses.textLa: Sive ergo manducatis, sive bibitis, sive aliud quid facitis: omnia in gloriam Dei facite.

verses.textEn: Be without offense toward the Jews, and toward the Gentiles, and toward the Church of God,
verses.textLa: Sine offensione estote Iudæis, et Gentibus, et Ecclesiæ Dei:

verses.textEn: just as I also, in all things, please everyone, not seeking what is best for myself, but what is best for many others, so that they may be saved.
verses.textLa: sicut et ego per omnia omnibus placeo, non quærens quod mihi utile est, sed quod multis: ut salvi fiant.

verses.textEn: Be imitators of me, as I also am of Christ.
verses.textLa: Imitatores mei estote, sicut et ego Christi.

verses.textEn: Now I praise you, brothers, because you are mindful of me in everything, in such a way as to hold to my precepts as I have handed them down to you.
verses.textLa: Laudo autem vos fratres quod per omnia mei memores estis: et sicut tradidi vobis, præcepta mea tenetis.

verses.textEn: So I want you to know that the head of every man is Christ. But the head of woman is man. Yet truly, the head of Christ is God.
verses.textLa: Volo autem vos scire quod omnis viri caput, Christus est: caput autem mulieris, vir: caput vero Christi, Deus.
verses.notes: This passage does not use ‘vir’ or ‘viri’ to refer to ‘husband,’ but more generally to ‘man.’ This is clear because the same word ‘vir’ is used consistently, even when there is no marriage relationship at issue, e.g. ‘the head of every man is Christ.’ Not every man is a husband, so vir and viri in this context mean man, not husband.

verses.textEn: Every man praying or prophesying with his head covered disgraces his head.
verses.textLa: Omnis vir orans, aut prophetans velato capite, deturpat caput suum.

verses.textEn: But every woman praying or prophesying with her head not covered disgraces her head. For it is the same as if her head were shaven.
verses.textLa: Omnis autem mulier orans, aut prophetans non velato capite, deturpat caput suum: unum enim est ac si decalvetur.

verses.textEn: So if a woman is not veiled, let her hair be cut off. Truly then, if it is a disgrace for a woman to have her hair cut off, or to have her head shaven, then she should cover her head.
verses.textLa: Nam si non velatur mulier, tondeatur. Si vero turpe est mulieri tonderi, aut decalvari, velet caput suum.

verses.textEn: Certainly, a man ought not to cover his head, for he is the image and glory of God. But woman is the glory of man.
verses.textLa: Vir quidem non debet velare caput suum: quoniam imago et gloria Dei est, mulier autem gloria viri est.

verses.textEn: For man is not of woman, but woman is of man.
verses.textLa: Non enim vir ex muliere est, sed mulier ex viro.

verses.textEn: And indeed, man was not created for woman, but woman was created for man.
verses.textLa: Etenim non est creatus vir propter mulierem, sed mulier propter virum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, a woman ought to have a sign of authority on her head, because of the Angels.
verses.textLa: Ideo debet mulier potestatem habere supra caput propter Angelos.
verses.notes: The veil or headcovering is a symbol if the order in creation, which includes Angels as well as men. For even among the Angels, there is order and levels of authority. The Angels are not all the same, they do not all have the same role, and some Angels have authority over other Angels. The holy Angels are offended when women pray without a headcovering, or when women take roles which God intends only for men. For the holy Angels keep to their proper places and are obedient to those Angels in authority over them. But the fallen angels rebelled by disobedience and by refusing to accept Christ as their head, as someone with authority over them; and so they destined themselves for Hell. Women who refuse to wear a veil, or who dress like a man, or who take a man’s role, are being disobedient to Christ and are disrespecting their head, repeating in miniature the same fault of disobedience and disrespect that caused some Angels to fall from grace. When the holy Angels see such disorder and disobedience by women towards their head, they remember the fall of the disobedient angels and they cringe.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, man would not exist without woman, nor would woman exist without man, in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen neque vir sine muliere: neque mulier sine viro in Domino.

verses.textEn: For just as woman came into existence from man, so also does man exist through woman. But all things are from God.
verses.textLa: Nam sicut mulier de viro, ita et vir per mulierem: omnia autem ex Deo.

verses.textEn: Judge for yourselves. Is it proper for a woman to pray to God unveiled?
verses.textLa: Vos ipsi iudicate: decet mulierem non velatam orare Deum?

verses.textEn: Does not even nature herself teach you that, indeed, if a man grows his hair long, it is a disgrace for him?
verses.textLa: Nec ipsa natura docet vos, quod vir quidem si comam nutriat, ignominia est illi:
verses.notes: Men are reflections of God, having the role of headship within humanity; women are reflections of Creation, that is, of nature, because God is the head of nature, just as man is the head of woman. Thus nature is referred to as ‘herself’.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, if a woman grows her hair long, it is a glory for her, because her hair has been given to her as a covering.
verses.textLa: mulier vero si comam nutriat, gloria est illi: quoniam capilli pro velamine ei dati sunt.

verses.textEn: But if anyone has a mind to be contentious, we have no such custom, nor does the Church of God.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem videtur contentiosus esse: nos talem consuetudinem non habemus, neque Ecclesia Dei.
verses.notes: So, if you cannot see the wisdom of this teaching, then Paul says to at least accept it because it is a custom in the Church of God; there should be no other custom.

verses.textEn: Now I caution you, without praising, about this: that you assemble together, and not for better, but for worse.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem præcipio, non laudans: quod non in melius, sed in deterius convenitis.

verses.textEn: First of all, indeed, I hear that when you assemble together in the church, there are schisms among you. And I believe this, in part.
verses.textLa: Primum quidem convenientibus vobis in Ecclesiam, audio scissuras esse inter vos, et ex parte credo.

verses.textEn: For there must also be heresies, so that those who have been tested may be made manifest among you.
verses.textLa: Nam oportet et hæreses esse, ut et qui probati sunt, manifesti fiant in vobis.

verses.textEn: And so, when you assemble together as one, it is no longer in order to eat the Lord’s supper.
verses.textLa: Convenientibus ergo vobis in unum, iam non est Dominicam cœnam manducare.

verses.textEn: For each one first takes his own supper to eat. And as a result, one person is hungry, while another is inebriated.
verses.textLa: Unusquisque enim suam cœnam præsumit ad manducandum. Et alius quidem esurit: alius autem ebrius est.

verses.textEn: Do you not have houses, in which to eat and drink? Or do you have such contempt for the Church of God that you would confound those who do not have such contempt? What should I say to you? Should I praise you? I am not praising you in this.
verses.textLa: Numquid domos non habetis ad manducandum, et bibendum? Aut Ecclesiam Dei contemnitis, et confunditis eos, qui non habent? Quid dicam vobis? Laudo vos? In hoc non laudo.

verses.textEn: For I have received from the Lord what I have also delivered to you: that the Lord Jesus, on the same night that he was handed over, took bread,
verses.textLa: Ego enim accepi a Domino quod et tradidi vobis, quoniam Dominus Iesus in qua nocte tradebatur, accepit panem,

verses.textEn: and giving thanks, he broke it, and said: “Take and eat. This is my body, which shall be given up for you. Do this in remembrance of me.”
verses.textLa: et gratias agens fregit, et dixit: Accipite, et manducate: hoc est corpus meum, quod pro vobis tradetur: hoc facite in meam commemorationem.

verses.textEn: Similarly also, the cup, after he had eaten supper, saying: “This cup is the new covenant in my blood. Do this, as often as you drink it, in remembrance of me.”
verses.textLa: Similiter et calicem, postquam cœnavit, dicens: Hic calix novum testamentum est in meo sanguine. Hoc facite quotiescumque bibetis, in meam commemorationem.

verses.textEn: For whenever you eat this bread and drink this cup, you proclaim the death of the Lord, until he returns.
verses.textLa: Quotiescumque enim manducabitis panem hunc, et calicem bibetis: mortem Domini annunciabitis donec veniat.

verses.textEn: And so, whoever eats this bread, or drinks from the cup of the Lord, unworthily, shall be liable of the body and blood of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Itaque quicumque manducaverit panem hunc, vel biberit calicem Domini indigne: reus erit corporis, et sanguinis Domini.

verses.textEn: But let a man examine himself, and, in this way, let him eat from that bread, and drink from that cup.
verses.textLa: Probet autem seipsum homo: et sic de pane illo edat, et de calice bibat.

verses.textEn: For whoever eats and drinks unworthily, eats and drinks a sentence against himself, not discerning it to be the body of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Qui enim manducat, et bibit indigne, iudicium sibi manducat, et bibit: non diiudicans corpus Domini.

verses.textEn: As a result, many are weak and sick among you, and many have fallen asleep.
verses.textLa: Ideo inter vos multi infirmi et imbecilles, et dormiunt multi.

verses.textEn: But if we ourselves were discerning, then certainly we would not be judged.
verses.textLa: Quod si nosmetipsos diiudicaremus, non utique iudicaremur.

verses.textEn: Yet when we are judged, we are being corrected by the Lord, so that we might not be condemned along with this world.
verses.textLa: Dum iudicamur autem, a Domino corripimur, ut non cum hoc mundo damnemur.

verses.textEn: And so, my brothers, when you assemble together to eat, be attentive to one another.
verses.textLa: Itaque fratres mei, cum convenitis ad manducandum, invicem expectate.

verses.textEn: If anyone is hungry, let him eat at home, so that you may not assemble together unto judgment. As for the rest, I will set it in order when I arrive.
verses.textLa: Si quis esurit, domi manducet: ut non in iudicium conveniatis. Cetera autem, cum venero, disponam.

verses.textEn: Now concerning spiritual things, I do not want you to be ignorant, brothers.
verses.textLa: De spiritualibus autem, nolo vos ignorare fratres.

verses.textEn: You know that when you were Gentiles, you approached mute idols, doing what you were led to do.
verses.textLa: Scitis quoniam cum Gentes essetis, ad simulachra muta prout ducebamini euntes.

verses.textEn: Because of this, I would have you know that no one speaking in the Spirit of God utters a curse against Jesus. And no one is able to say that Jesus is Lord, except in the Holy Spirit.
verses.textLa: Ideo notum vobis facio, quod nemo in Spiritu Dei loquens, dicit anathema Iesu. Et nemo potest dicere, Dominus Iesus, nisi in Spiritu Sancto.

verses.textEn: Truly, there are diverse graces, but the same Spirit.
verses.textLa: Divisiones vero gratiarum sunt, idem autem Spiritus:

verses.textEn: And there are diverse ministries, but the same Lord.
verses.textLa: Et divisiones ministrationum sunt, idem autem Dominus:

verses.textEn: And there are diverse works, but the same God, who works everything in everyone.
verses.textLa: Et divisiones operationum sunt, idem vero Deus, qui operatur omnia in omnibus.

verses.textEn: However, the manifestation of the Spirit is given to each one toward what is beneficial.
verses.textLa: Unicuique autem datur manifestatio Spiritus ad utilitatem.

verses.textEn: Certainly, to one, through the Spirit, is given words of wisdom; but to another, according to the same Spirit, words of knowledge;
verses.textLa: Alii quidem per Spiritum datur sermo sapientiæ: alii autem sermo scientiæ secundum eundem Spiritum:

verses.textEn: to another, in the same Spirit, faith; to another, in the one Spirit, the gift of healing;
verses.textLa: alteri fides in eodem Spiritu: alii gratia sanitatum in uno Spiritu:

verses.textEn: to another, miraculous works; to another, prophecy; to another, the discernment of spirits; to another, different kinds of languages; to another, the interpretation of words.
verses.textLa: alii operatio virtutum, alii prophetia, alii discretio spirituum, alii genera linguarum, alii interpretatio sermonum.

verses.textEn: But one and the same Spirit works all these things, distributing to each one according to his will.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem omnia operantur unus atque idem Spiritus, dividens singulis prout vult.

verses.textEn: For just as the body is one, and yet has many parts, so all the parts of the body, though they are many, are only one body. So also is Christ.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim corpus unum est, et membra habet multa, omnia autem membra corporis cum sint multa, unum tamen corpus sunt: ita et Christus.

verses.textEn: And indeed, in one Spirit, we were all baptized into one body, whether Jews or Gentiles, whether servant or free. And we all drank in the one Spirit.
verses.textLa: Etenim in uno Spiritu omnes nos in unum corpus baptizati sumus, sive Iudæi, sive Gentiles, sive servi, sive liberi: et omnes in uno Spiritu potati sumus.

verses.textEn: For the body, too, is not one part, but many.
verses.textLa: Nam et corpus non est unum membrum, sed multa.

verses.textEn: If the foot were to say, “Because I am not the hand, I am not of the body,” would it then not be of the body?
verses.textLa: Si dixerit pes: Quoniam non sum manus, non sum de corpore: num ideo non est de corpore?

verses.textEn: And if the ear were to say, “Because I am not the eye, I am not of the body,” would it then not be of the body?
verses.textLa: Et si dixerit auris: Quoniam non sum oculus, non sum de corpore: num ideo est de corpore?

verses.textEn: If the whole body were the eye, how would it hear? If the whole were hearing, how would it smell?
verses.textLa: Si totum corpus oculus: ubi auditus? Si totum auditus: ubi odoratus?

verses.textEn: But instead, God has placed the parts, each one of them, in the body, just as it has pleased him.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem posuit Deus membra, unumquodque eorum in corpore sicut voluit.

verses.textEn: So if they were all one part, how would it be a body?
verses.textLa: Quod si essent omnia unum membrum, ubi corpus?

verses.textEn: But instead, there are many parts, indeed, yet one body.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem multa quidem membra, unum autem corpus.

verses.textEn: And the eye cannot say to the hand, “I have no need for your works.” And again, the head cannot say to the feet, “You are of no use to me.”
verses.textLa: Non potest autem oculus dicere manui: Opera tua non indigeo: aut iterum caput pedibus: Non estis mihi necessarii.

verses.textEn: In fact, so much more necessary are those parts of the body which seem to be weaker.
verses.textLa: Sed multo magis quæ videntur membra corporis infirmiora esse, necessariora sunt:

verses.textEn: And though we consider certain parts of the body to be less noble, we surround these with more abundant dignity, and so, those parts which are less presentable end up with more abundant respect.
verses.textLa: et quæ putamus ignobiliora membra esse corporis, his honorem abundantiorem circumdamus: et quæ inhonesta sunt nostra, abundantiorem honestatem habent.

verses.textEn: However, our presentable parts have no such need, since God has tempered the body together, distributing the more abundant honor to that which has the need,
verses.textLa: Honesta autem nostra nullius egent: sed Deus temperavit corpus, ei, cui deerat, abundationem tribuendo honorem,

verses.textEn: so that there might be no schism in the body, but instead the parts themselves might take care of one another.
verses.textLa: ut non sit schisma in corpore, sed idipsum pro invicem solicita sint membra.

verses.textEn: And so, if one part suffers anything, all the parts suffer with it. Or, if one part finds glory, all the parts rejoice with it.
verses.textLa: Et si quid patitur unum membrum, compatiuntur omnia membra: sive gloriatur unum membrum, congaudent omnia membra.

verses.textEn: Now you are the body of Christ, and parts like any part.
verses.textLa: Vos autem estis corpus Christi, et membra de membro.

verses.textEn: And indeed, God has established a certain order in the Church: first Apostles, second Prophets, third Teachers, next miracle-workers, and then the grace of healing, of helping others, of governing, of different kinds of languages, and of the interpretation of words.
verses.textLa: Et quosdam quidem posuit Deus in Ecclesia primum Apostolos, secundo Prophetas, exinde Doctores, deinde virtutes, exinde gratias curationum, opitulationes, gubernationes, genera linguarum, interpretationes sermonum.

verses.textEn: Are all Apostles? Are all Prophets? Are all Teachers?
verses.textLa: Numquid omnes Apostoli? Numquid omnes Prophetæ? numquid omnes Doctores?

verses.textEn: Are all workers of miracles? Do all have the grace of healing? Do all speak in tongues? Do all interpret?
verses.textLa: Numquid omnes virtutes? Numquid omnes gratiam habent curationum? Numquid omnes linguis loquuntur? Numquid omnes interpretantur?

verses.textEn: But be zealous for the better charisms. And I reveal to you a yet more excellent way.
verses.textLa: Æmulamini autem charismata meliora. Et adhuc excellentiorem viam vobis demonstro.
