verses.textEn: If I were to speak in the language of men, or of Angels, yet not have charity, I would be like a clanging bell or a crashing cymbal.
verses.textLa: Si linguis hominum loquar, et Angelorum, charitatem autem non habeam, factus sum velut æs sonans, aut cymbalum tinniens.

verses.textEn: And if I have prophecy, and learn every mystery, and obtain all knowledge, and possess all faith, so that I could move mountains, yet not have charity, then I am nothing.
verses.textLa: Et si habuero prophetiam, et noverim mysteria omnia, et omnem scientiam: et si habuero omnem fidem ita ut montes transferam, charitatem autem non habuero, nihil sum.

verses.textEn: And if I distribute all my goods in order to feed the poor, and if I hand over my body to be burned, yet not have charity, it offers me nothing.
verses.textLa: Et si distribuero in cibos pauperum omnes facultates meas, et si tradidero corpus meum ita ut ardeam, charitatem autem non habuero, nihil mihi prodest.

verses.textEn: Charity is patient, is kind. Charity does not envy, does not act wrongly, is not inflated.
verses.textLa: Charitas patiens est, benigna est. Charitas non æmulatur, non agit perperam, non inflatur,

verses.textEn: Charity is not ambitious, does not seek for itself, is not provoked to anger, devises no evil.
verses.textLa: non est ambitiosa, non quærit quæ sua sunt, non irritatur, non cogitat malum,

verses.textEn: Charity does not rejoice over iniquity, but rejoices in truth.
verses.textLa: non gaudet super iniquitate, congaudet autem veritati:

verses.textEn: Charity suffers all, believes all, hopes all, endures all.
verses.textLa: omnia suffert, omnia credit, omnia sperat, omnia sustinet.

verses.textEn: Charity is never torn away, even if prophecies pass away, or languages cease, or knowledge is destroyed.
verses.textLa: Charitas numquam excidit: sive prophetiæ evacuabuntur, sive linguæ cessabunt, sive scientia destruetur.

verses.textEn: For we know only in part, and we prophesy only in part.
verses.textLa: Ex parte enim cognoscimus, et ex parte prophetamus.

verses.textEn: But when the perfect arrives, the imperfect passes away.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venerit quod perfectum est, evacuabitur quod ex parte est.

verses.textEn: When I was a child, I spoke like a child, I understood like a child, I thought like a child. But when I became a man, I put aside the things of a child.
verses.textLa: Cum essem parvulus, loquebar ut parvulus, sapiebam ut parvulus, cogitabam ut parvulus. Quando autem factus sum vir, evacuavi quæ erant parvuli.

verses.textEn: Now we see through a glass darkly. But then we shall see face to face. Now I know in part, but then I shall know, even as I am known.
verses.textLa: Videmus nunc per speculum in ænigmate: tunc autem facie ad faciem. Nunc cognosco ex parte: tunc autem cognoscam sicut et cognitus sum.

verses.textEn: But for now, these three continue: faith, hope, and charity. And the greatest of these is charity.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem manent, fides, spes, charitas: tria hæc. Maior autem horum est charitas.

verses.textEn: Pursue charity. Be zealous for spiritual things, but only so that you may prophesy.
verses.textLa: Sectamini charitatem, æmulamini spiritualia: magis autem ut prophetetis.

verses.textEn: For whoever speaks in tongues, speaks not to men, but to God. For no one understands. Yet by the Spirit, he speaks mysteries.
verses.textLa: Qui enim loquitur lingua, non hominibus loquitur, sed Deo: nemo enim audit. Spiritu autem loquitur mysteria.

verses.textEn: But whoever prophesies speaks to men for edification and exhortation and consolation.
verses.textLa: Nam qui prophetat, hominibus loquitur ad ædificationem, et exhortationem, et consolationem.

verses.textEn: Whoever speaks in tongues edifies himself. But whoever prophesies edifies the Church.
verses.textLa: Qui loquitur lingua, semetipsum ædificat: qui autem prophetat, Ecclesiam Dei ædificat.

verses.textEn: Now I want you all to speak in tongues, but more so to prophesy. For he who prophesies is greater than he who speaks in tongues, unless perhaps he interprets, so that the Church may receive edification.
verses.textLa: Volo autem omnes vos loqui linguis: magis autem prophetare. Nam maior est qui prophetat, quam qui loquitur linguis: nisi forte interpretetur ut Ecclesia ædificationem accipiat.

verses.textEn: But now, brothers, if I were to come to you speaking in tongues, how would it benefit you, unless instead I speak to you in revelation, or in knowledge, or in prophecy, or in doctrine?
verses.textLa: Nunc autem, fratres, si venero ad vos linguis loquens: quid vobis prodero, nisi vobis loquar aut in revelatione, aut in scientia, aut in prophetia, aut in doctrina?

verses.textEn: Even those things that are without a soul can make sounds, whether it is a wind or a stringed instrument. But unless they present a distinction within the sounds, how will it be known which is from the pipe and which is from the string?
verses.textLa: Tamen quæ sine anima sunt vocem dantia, sive tibia, sive cithara: nisi distinctionem sonituum dederint, quomodo scietur id, quod canitur, aut quod citharizatur?

verses.textEn: For example, if the trumpet made an uncertain sound, who would prepare himself for battle?
verses.textLa: Etenim si incertam vocem det tuba, quis parabit se ad bellum?

verses.textEn: So it is with you also, for unless you utter with the tongue in plain speech, how will it be known what is said? For then you would be speaking into the air.
verses.textLa: Ita et vos per linguam nisi manifestum sermonem dederitis: quomodo scietur id, quod dicitur? Eritis enim in aera loquentes.

verses.textEn: Consider that there are so many different kinds of languages in this world, and yet none is without a voice.
verses.textLa: Tam multa, ut puta genera linguarum sunt in hoc mundo: et nihil sine voce est.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if I do not understand the nature of the voice, then I shall be like a foreigner to the one with whom I am speaking; and he who is speaking will be like a foreigner to me.
verses.textLa: Si ergo nesciero virtutem vocis, ero ei, cui loquor, barbarus: et qui loquitur, mihi barbarus:

verses.textEn: So it is with you also. And since you are zealous for what is spiritual, seek the edification of the Church, so that you may abound.
verses.textLa: Sic et vos, quoniam æmulatores estis spirituum, ad ædificationem Ecclesiæ quærite ut abundetis.

verses.textEn: For this reason, too, whoever speaks in tongues, let him pray for the interpretation.
verses.textLa: Et ideo qui loquitur lingua: oret ut interpretetur.

verses.textEn: So, if I pray in tongues, my spirit prays, but my mind is without fruit.
verses.textLa: Nam si orem lingua, spiritus meus orat, mens autem mea sine fructu est.

verses.textEn: What is next? I should pray with the spirit, and also pray with the mind. I should sing psalms with the spirit, and also recite psalms with the mind.
verses.textLa: Quid ergo est? Orabo spiritu, orabo et mente: psallam spiritu, psallam et mente.

verses.textEn: Otherwise, if you have blessed only with the spirit, how can someone, in a state of ignorance, add an “Amen” to your blessing? For he does not know what you are saying.
verses.textLa: Ceterum si benedixeris spiritu: qui supplet locum idiotæ, quomodo dicet, Amen, super tuam benedictionem? Quoniam quid dicas, nescit.

verses.textEn: In this case, certainly, you give thanks well, but the other person is not edified.
verses.textLa: Nam tu quidem bene gratias agis: sed alter non ædificatur.

verses.textEn: I thank my God that I speak in tongues for all of you.
verses.textLa: Gratias ago Deo meo, quod omnium vestrum lingua loquor.

verses.textEn: But in the Church, I prefer to speak five words from my mind, so that I may instruct others also, rather than ten thousand words in tongues.
verses.textLa: Sed in Ecclesia volo quinque verba sensu meo loqui, ut et alios instruam: quam decem millia verborum in lingua.

verses.textEn: Brothers, do not choose to have the minds of children. Instead, be free of malice like infants, but be mature in your minds.
verses.textLa: Fratres, nolite pueri effici sensibus, sed malitia parvuli estote: sensibus autem perfecti estote.
verses.notes: Little children have no malice. So telling someone to be child-like with respect to malice means not be have malice. Be child-like with respect to evil, in that little ones lack evil. But be mature in the faith and in your understanding of the Faith.

verses.textEn: It is written in the law: “I will speak to this people with other tongues and other lips, and even so, they will not heed me, says the Lord.”
verses.textLa: In lege scriptum est: Quoniam in aliis linguis et labiis aliis loquar populo huic: et nec sic exaudient me, dicit Dominus.

verses.textEn: And so, tongues are a sign, not for believers, but for unbelievers; and prophecies are not for unbelievers, but for believers.
verses.textLa: Itaque linguæ in signum sunt non fidelibus, sed infidelibus: prophetiæ autem non infidelibus, sed fidelibus.

verses.textEn: If then, the entire Church were to gather together as one, and if all were to speak in tongues, and then ignorant or unbelieving persons were to enter, would they not say that you were insane?
verses.textLa: Si ergo conveniat universa Ecclesia in unum, et omnes linguis loquantur, intrent autem idiotæ, aut infideles: nonne dicent quod insanitis?

verses.textEn: But if everyone prophesies, and one who is ignorant or unbelieving enters, he may be convinced by it all, because he understands it all.
verses.textLa: Si autem omnes prophetent, intret autem quis infidelis, vel idiota, convincitur ab omnibus, diiudicatur ab omnibus:

verses.textEn: The secrets of his heart are then made manifest. And so, falling to his face, he would adore God, proclaiming that God is truly among you.
verses.textLa: occulta cordis eius manifesta fiunt: et ita cadens in faciem adorabit Deum, pronuncians quod vere Deus in vobis sit.

verses.textEn: What is next, brothers? When you gather together, each one of you may have a psalm, or a doctrine, or a revelation, or a language, or an interpretation, but let everything be done for edification.
verses.textLa: Quid ergo est, fratres? Cum convenitis, unusquisque vestrum psalmum habet, doctrinam habet, apocalypsim habet, linguam habet, interpretationem habet: omnia ad ædificationem fiant.

verses.textEn: If anyone is speaking in tongues, let there be only two, or at most three, and then in turn, and let someone interpret.
verses.textLa: Sive lingua quis loquitur, secundum duos, aut ut multum tres, et per partes, et unus interpretatur.

verses.textEn: But if there is no one to interpret, he should remain silent in the church, then he may speak when he is alone with God.
verses.textLa: Si autem non fuerit interpres, taceat in ecclesia, sibi autem loquatur, et Deo.

verses.textEn: And let the prophets speak, two or three, and let the others discern.
verses.textLa: Prophetæ autem duo, aut tres dicant, et ceteri diiudicent.

verses.textEn: But then, if something is revealed to another who is sitting, let the first one become silent.
verses.textLa: Quod si alii revelatum fuerit sedenti, prior taceat.

verses.textEn: For you are all able to prophesy one at a time, so that all may learn and all may be encouraged.
verses.textLa: Potestis enim omnes per singulos prophetare: ut omnes discant, et omnes exhortentur:

verses.textEn: For the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets.
verses.textLa: et spiritus prophetarum prophetis subiecti sunt.

verses.textEn: And God is not of dissension, but of peace, just as I also teach in all the churches of the saints.
verses.textLa: Non enim est dissensionis Deus, sed pacis: sicut et in omnibus Ecclesiis sanctorum doceo.

verses.textEn: Women should be silent in the churches. For it is not permitted for them to speak; but instead, they should be subordinate, as the law also says.
verses.textLa: Mulieres in Ecclesiis taceant, non enim permittitur eis loqui, sed subditas esse, sicut et lex dicit.

verses.textEn: And if they want to learn anything, let them ask their husbands at home. For it is disgraceful for a woman to speak in church.
verses.textLa: Si quid autem volunt discere, domi viros suos interrogent. Turpe est enim mulieri loqui in Ecclesia.

verses.textEn: So now, did the Word of God proceed from you? Or was it sent to you alone?
verses.textLa: An a vobis Verbum Dei processit? Aut in vos solos pervenit?

verses.textEn: If anyone seems to be a prophet or a spiritual person, he should understand these things which I am writing to you, that these things are the commandments of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Si quis videtur propheta esse, aut spiritualis, cognoscat quæ scribo vobis, quia Domini sunt mandata.

verses.textEn: If anyone does not recognize these things, he should not be recognized.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem ignorat, ignorabitur.

verses.textEn: And so, brothers, be zealous to prophesy, and do not prohibit speaking in tongues.
verses.textLa: Itaque fratres æmulamini prophetare: et loqui linguis nolite prohibere.

verses.textEn: But let everything be done respectfully and according to proper order.
verses.textLa: Omnia autem honeste, et secundum ordinem fiant.

verses.textEn: And so I make known to you, brothers, the Gospel that I preached to you, which you also received, and on which you stand.
verses.textLa: Notum autem vobis facio, fratres, Evangelium, quod prædicavi vobis, quod et accepistis, in quo et statis,

verses.textEn: By the Gospel, too, you are being saved, if you hold to the understanding that I preached to you, lest you believe in vain.
verses.textLa: per quod et salvamini: qua ratione prædicaverim vobis, si tenetis, nisi frustra credidistis.

verses.textEn: For I handed on to you, first of all, what I also received: that Christ died for our sins, according to the Scriptures;
verses.textLa: Tradidi enim vobis in primis quod et accepi: quoniam Christus mortuus est pro peccatis nostris secundum Scripturas:

verses.textEn: and that he was buried; and that he rose again on the third day, according to the Scriptures;
verses.textLa: et quia sepultus est, et quia resurrexit tertia die secundum Scripturas:

verses.textEn: and that he was seen by Cephas, and after that by the eleven.
verses.textLa: et quia visus est Cephæ, et post hoc undecim:

verses.textEn: Next he was seen by more than five hundred brothers at one time, many of whom remain, even to the present time, although some have fallen asleep.
verses.textLa: Deinde visus est plus quam quingentis fratribus simul: ex quibus multi manent usque adhuc, quidam autem dormierunt:

verses.textEn: Next, he was seen by James, then by all the Apostles.
verses.textLa: Deinde visus est Iacobo, deinde Apostolis omnibus:

verses.textEn: And last of all, he was seen also by me, as if I were someone born at the wrong time.
verses.textLa: Novissime autem omnium tamquam abortivo, visus est et mihi.

verses.textEn: For I am the least of the Apostles. I am not worthy to be called an Apostle, because I persecuted the Church of God.
verses.textLa: Ego enim sum minimus Apostolorum, qui non sum dignus vocari Apostolus, quoniam persecutus sum Ecclesiam Dei.

verses.textEn: But, by the grace of God, I am what I am. And his grace in me has not been empty, since I have labored more abundantly than all of them. Yet it is not I, but the grace of God within me.
verses.textLa: Gratia autem Dei sum id, quod sum: et gratia eius in me vacua non fuit, sed abundantius illis omnibus laboravi: non ego autem, sed gratia Dei mecum:

verses.textEn: For whether it is I or they: so we preach, and so you have believed.
verses.textLa: Sive enim ego, sive illi: sic prædicamus, et sic credidistis.

verses.textEn: Now if Christ is preached, that he rose again from the dead, how is it that some among you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?
verses.textLa: Si autem Christus prædicatur quod resurrexit a mortuis, quomodo quidam dicunt in vobis, quoniam resurrectio mortuorum non est?

verses.textEn: For if there is no resurrection of the dead, then Christ has not risen.
verses.textLa: Si autem resurrectio mortuorum non est: neque Christus resurrexit.

verses.textEn: And if Christ has not risen, then our preaching is useless, and your faith is also useless.
verses.textLa: Si autem Christus non resurrexit, inanis est ergo prædicatio nostra, inanis est et fides vestra:

verses.textEn: Then, too, we would be found to be false witnesses of God, because we would have given testimony against God, saying that he had raised up Christ, when he had not raised him up, if, indeed, the dead do not rise again.
verses.textLa: invenimur autem et falsi testes Dei: quoniam testimonium diximus adversus Deum quod suscitaverit Christum, quem non suscitavit, si mortui non resurgunt.

verses.textEn: For if the dead do not rise again, then neither has Christ risen again.
verses.textLa: Nam si mortui non resurgunt, neque Christus resurrexit.

verses.textEn: But if Christ has not risen, then your faith is vain; for you would still be in your sins.
verses.textLa: Quod si Christus non resurrexit, vana est fides vestra, adhuc enim estis in peccatis vestris.

verses.textEn: Then, too, those who have fallen asleep in Christ would have perished.
verses.textLa: Ergo et qui dormierunt in Christo, perierunt.

verses.textEn: If we have hope in Christ for this life only, then we are more miserable than all men.
verses.textLa: Si in hac vita tantum in Christo sperantes sumus, miserabiliores sumus omnibus hominibus.

verses.textEn: But now Christ has risen again from the dead, as the first-fruits of those who sleep.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem Christus resurrexit a mortuis primitiæ dormientium,

verses.textEn: For certainly, death came through a man. And so, the resurrection of the dead came through a man
verses.textLa: quoniam quidem per hominem mors, et per hominem resurrectio mortuorum.

verses.textEn: And just as in Adam all die, so also in Christ all will be brought to life,
verses.textLa: Et sicut in Adam omnes moriuntur, ita et in Christo omnes vivificabuntur.

verses.textEn: but each one in his proper order: Christ, as the first-fruits, and next, those who are of Christ, who have believed in his advent.
verses.textLa: Unusquisque autem in suo ordine, primitiæ Christus: deinde ii, qui sunt Christi, qui in adventu eius crediderunt.

verses.textEn: Afterwards is the end, when he will have handed over the kingdom to God the Father, when he will have emptied all principality, and authority, and power.
verses.textLa: Deinde finis: cum tradiderit regnum Deo et Patri, cum evacuaverit omnem principatum, et potestatem, et virtutem.

verses.textEn: For it is necessary for him to reign, until he has set all his enemies under his feet.
verses.textLa: Oportet autem illum regnare donec ponat omnes inimicos sub pedibus eius.

verses.textEn: Lastly, the enemy called death shall be destroyed. For he has subjected all things under his feet. And although he says,
verses.textLa: Novissima autem inimica destruetur mors: Omnia enim subiecit pedibus eius. Cum autem dicat:

verses.textEn: “All things have been subjected to him,” without doubt he does not include the One who has subjected all things to him.
verses.textLa: Omnia subiecta sunt ei, sine dubio præter eum, qui subiecit ei omnia.

verses.textEn: And when all things will have been subjected to him, then even the Son himself will be subjected to the One who subjected all things to him, so that God may be all in all.
verses.textLa: Cum autem subiecta fuerint illi omnia: tunc et ipse Filius subiectus erit ei, qui subiecit sibi omnia, ut sit Deus omnia in omnibus.

verses.textEn: Otherwise, what will those who are being baptized for the dead do, if the dead do not rise again at all? Why then are they being baptized for them?
verses.textLa: Alioquin quid facient qui baptizantur pro mortuis, si omnino mortui non resurgunt? Ut quid et baptizantur pro illis?

verses.textEn: Why also do we endure trials every hour?
verses.textLa: Ut quid et nos periclitamur omni hora?

verses.textEn: Daily I die, by means of your boasting, brothers: you whom I have in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.textLa: Quotidie morior per vestram gloriam, fratres, quam habeo in Christo Iesu Domino nostro.

verses.textEn: If, according to man, I fought with the beasts at Ephesus, how would that benefit me, if the dead do not rise again? “Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we shall die.”
verses.textLa: Si (secundum hominem) ad bestias pugnavi Ephesi, quid mihi prodest, si mortui non resurgunt? Manducemus, et bibamus, cras enim moriemur.

verses.textEn: Do not be led astray. Evil communication corrupts good morals.
verses.textLa: Nolite seduci: Corrumpunt mores bonos colloquia mala.

verses.textEn: Be vigilant, you just ones, and do not be willing to sin. For certain persons have an ignorance of God. I say this to you with respect.
verses.textLa: Evigilate iusti, et nolite peccare: ignorantiam enim Dei quidam habent, ad reverentiam vobis loquor.

verses.textEn: But someone may say, “How do the dead rise again?” or, “What type of body do they return with?”
verses.textLa: Sed dicet aliquis: Quomodo resurgunt mortui? Qualive corpore venient?

verses.textEn: How foolish! What you sow cannot be brought back to life, unless it first dies.
verses.textLa: Insipiens, tu quod seminas non vivificatur, nisi prius moriatur.

verses.textEn: And what you sow is not the body that will be in the future, but a bare grain, such as of wheat, or of some other grain.
verses.textLa: Et quod seminas, non corpus, quod futurum est, seminas, sed nudum granum, ut puta tritici, aut alicuius ceterorum.

verses.textEn: For God gives it a body according to his will, and according to each seed’s proper body.
verses.textLa: Deus autem dat illi corpus sicut vult: ut unicuique seminum proprium corpus.

verses.textEn: Not all flesh is the same flesh. But one is indeed of men, another truly is of beasts, another is of birds, and another is of fish.
verses.textLa: Non omnis caro, eadem caro: sed alia quidem hominum, alia vero pecorum, alia volucrum, alia autem piscium.

verses.textEn: Also, there are heavenly bodies and earthly bodies. But while the one, certainly, has the glory of heaven, the other has the glory of earth.
verses.textLa: Et corpora cælestia, et corpora terrestria: sed alia quidem cælestium gloria, alia autem terrestrium:

verses.textEn: One has the brightness of the sun, another the brightness of the moon, and another the brightness of the stars. For even star differs from star in brightness.
verses.textLa: Alia claritas solis, alia claritas lunæ, et alia claritas stellarum. Stella enim a stella differt in claritate:

verses.textEn: So it is also with the resurrection of the dead. What is sown in corruption shall rise to incorruption.
verses.textLa: sic et resurrectio mortuorum. Seminatur in corruptione, surget in incorruptione.

verses.textEn: What is sown in dishonor shall rise to glory. What is sown in weakness shall rise to power.
verses.textLa: Seminatur in ignobilitate, surget in gloria: Seminatur in infirmitate, surget in virtute:

verses.textEn: What is sown with an animal body shall rise with a spiritual body. If there is an animal body, there is also a spiritual one.
verses.textLa: Seminatur corpus animale, surget corpus spiritale. Si est corpus animale, est et spiritale, sicut scriptum est:

verses.textEn: Just as it was written that the first man, Adam, was made with a living soul, so shall the last Adam be made with a spirit brought back to life.
verses.textLa: Factus est primus homo Adam in animam viventem, novissimus Adam in spiritum vivificantem.

verses.textEn: So what is, at first, not spiritual, but animal, next becomes spiritual.
verses.textLa: Sed non prius quod spiritale est, sed quod animale: deinde quod spiritale.

verses.textEn: The first man, being earthly, was of the earth; the second man, being heavenly, will be of heaven.
verses.textLa: Primus homo de terra, terrenus: secundus homo de cælo, cælestis.

verses.textEn: Such things as are like the earth are earthly; and such things as are like the heavens are heavenly.
verses.textLa: Qualis terrenus, tales et terreni: et qualis cælestis, tales et cælestes.

verses.textEn: And so, just as we have carried the image of what is earthly, let us also carry the image of what is heavenly.
verses.textLa: Igitur, sicut portavimus imaginem terreni, portemus et imaginem cælestis.

verses.textEn: Now I say this, brothers, because flesh and blood is not able to possess the kingdom of God; neither will what is corrupt possess what is incorrupt.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem dico, fratres: quia caro et sanguis regnum Dei possidere non possunt: neque corruptio incorruptelam possidebit.

verses.textEn: Behold, I tell you a mystery. Certainly, we shall all rise again, but we shall not all be transformed:
verses.textLa: Ecce mysterium vobis dico: Omnes quidem resurgemus, sed non omnes immutabimur.
verses.notes: The just rise up with transformed incorruptible bodies; the unjust also rise up, but not with this type of holy transformation to incorruptibility. The bodies of the unjust are corrupt, even beyond the corruption of earthly bodies, for their resurrected bodies are neither of heaven, nor of earth, but of a new Hell, fit for body and soul.

verses.textEn: in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will sound, and the dead will rise up, incorruptible. And we shall be transformed.
verses.textLa: In momento, in ictu oculi, in novissima tuba: canet enim tuba, et mortui resurgent incorrupti: et nos immutabimur.

verses.textEn: Thus, it is necessary for this corruptibility to be clothed with incorruptibility, and for this mortality to be clothed with immortality.
verses.textLa: Oportet enim corruptibile hoc induere incorruptionem: et mortale hoc induere immortalitatem.

verses.textEn: And when this mortality has been clothed with immortality, then the word that was written shall occur: “Death is swallowed up in victory.”
verses.textLa: Cum autem mortale hoc induerit immortalitatem, tunc fiet sermo, qui scriptus est: Absorpta est mors in victoria.

verses.textEn: “O death, where is your victory? O death, where is your sting?”
verses.textLa: Ubi est mors victoria tua? Ubi est mors stimulus tuus?

verses.textEn: Now the sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
verses.textLa: Stimulus autem mortis peccatum est: virtus vero peccati lex.

verses.textEn: But thanks be to God, who has given us victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: Deo autem gratias, qui dedit nobis victoriam per Dominum nostrum Iesum Christum.

verses.textEn: And so, my beloved brothers, be steadfast and unmovable, abounding always in the work of the Lord, knowing that your labor is not useless in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Itaque fratres mei dilecti, stabiles estote, et immobiles: abundantes in opere Domini semper, scientes quod labor vester non est inanis in Domino.

verses.textEn: Now concerning the collections which are made for the saints: just as I have arranged for the churches of Galatia, so should it also be done with you.
verses.textLa: De collectis autem, quæ fiunt in sanctos, sicut ordinavi Ecclesiis Galatiæ, ita et vos facite.

verses.textEn: On the first day of the week, the Sabbath, let each one of you take from himself, setting aside what will be well-pleasing to him, so that when I arrive, the collections will not have to be made then.
verses.textLa: Per unam Sabbati unusquisque vestrum apud se seponat, recondens quod ei bene placuerit: ut non, cum venero, tunc collectæ fiant.

verses.textEn: And when I am present, whomever you shall approve through letters, these I shall send to bear your gifts to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Cum autem præsens fuero: quos probaveritis per epistolas, hos mittam perferre gratiam vestram in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And if it is fitting for me to go too, they shall go with me.
verses.textLa: Quod si dignum fuerit ut et ego eam, mecum ibunt.

verses.textEn: Now I will visit you after I have passed through Macedonia. For I will pass through Macedonia.
verses.textLa: Veniam autem ad vos, cum Macedoniam pertransiero: nam Macedoniam pertransibo.

verses.textEn: And perhaps I will stay with you, and even spend the winter, so that you may lead me on my way, whenever I depart.
verses.textLa: Apud vos autem forsitan manebo, vel etiam hiemabo: ut vos me deducatis quocumque iero.
verses.notes: The custom was to accompany someone who was departing on a long journey for part of the initial journey, for example, to the outskirts of the next city, or to main road some distance from the point of departure, etc.

verses.textEn: For I am not willing to see you now only in passing, since I hope that I may remain with you for some length of time, if the Lord permits.
verses.textLa: Nolo enim vos modo in transitu videre, spero enim me aliquantulum temporis manere apud vos, si Dominus permiserit.

verses.textEn: But I must remain at Ephesus, even until Pentecost.
verses.textLa: Permanebo autem Ephesi usque ad Pentecosten.

verses.textEn: For a door, great and unavoidable, has opened to me, as well as many adversaries.
verses.textLa: Ostium enim mihi apertum est magnum, et evidens: et adversarii multi.

verses.textEn: Now if Timothy arrives, see to it that he may be among you without fear. For he is doing the work of the Lord, just as I also do.
verses.textLa: Si autem venerit Timotheus, videte ut sine timore sit apud vos: opus enim Domini operatur, sicut et ego.

verses.textEn: Therefore, let no one despise him. Instead, lead him on his way in peace, so that he may come to me. For I am awaiting him with the brothers.
verses.textLa: Ne quis ergo illum spernat: deducite autem illum in pace, ut veniat ad me: expecto enim illum cum fratribus.

verses.textEn: But concerning our brother, Apollo, I am letting you know that I pleaded with him greatly to go to you with the brothers, and clearly it was not his will to go at this time. But he will arrive when there is a space of time for him.
verses.textLa: De Apollo autem fratre vobis notum facio, quoniam multum rogavi eum ut veniret ad vos cum fratribus: et utique non fuit voluntas ut nunc veniret: veniet autem, cum ei vacuum fuerit.

verses.textEn: Be vigilant. Stand with faith. Act manfully and be strengthened.
verses.textLa: Vigilate, state in fide, viriliter agite, et confortamini.

verses.textEn: Let all that is yours be immersed in charity.
verses.textLa: Omnia vestra in charitate fiant.
verses.notes: The word ‘fiant’ is the plural of the word ‘fiat’: let it be.

verses.textEn: And I beg you, brothers: You know the house of Stephanus, and of Fortunatus, and of Achaicus, that they are the first-fruits of Achaia, and that they have dedicated themselves to the ministry of the saints.
verses.textLa: Obsecro autem vos fratres, nostis domum Stephanæ, et Fortunati, et Achaici: quoniam sunt primitiæ Achaiæ, et in ministerium sanctorum ordinaverunt seipsos:

verses.textEn: So you should be subject also to persons such as this, as well as to all who are cooperating and working with them.
verses.textLa: ut et vos subditi sitis eiusmodi, et omni cooperanti, et laboranti.

verses.textEn: Now I rejoice in the presence of Stephanus and Fortunatus and Achaicus, because what was lacking in you, they have supplied.
verses.textLa: Gaudeo autem in præsentia Stephanæ, et Fortunati, et Achaici: quoniam id, quod vobis deerat, ipsi suppleverunt:

verses.textEn: For they have refreshed my spirit and yours. Therefore, recognize persons such as this.
verses.textLa: refecerunt enim et meum spiritum, et vestrum. Cognoscite ergo qui huiusmodi sunt.

verses.textEn: The churches of Asia greet you. Aquila and Priscilla greet you greatly in the Lord, with the church of their household, where I also am a guest.
verses.textLa: Salutant vos Ecclesiæ Asiæ. Salutant vos in Domino multum, Aquila, et Priscilla cum domestica sua Ecclesia: apud quos et hospitor.

verses.textEn: All the brothers greet you. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
verses.textLa: Salutant vos omnes fratres. Salutate invicem in osculo sancto.

verses.textEn: This is a greeting from my own hand, Paul.
verses.textLa: Salutatio, mea manu Pauli.

verses.textEn: If anyone does not love our Lord Jesus Christ, let him be anathema! Maran Atha.
verses.textLa: Si quis non amat Dominum nostrum Iesum Christum, sit anathema, Maran Atha.
verses.notes: The word ‘anathema’ means ‘cut off’ or ‘excommunicated’ or ‘accursed.’

verses.textEn: May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all.
verses.textLa: Gratia Domini nostri Iesu Christi vobiscum.

verses.textEn: My charity is with all of you in Christ Jesus. Amen.
verses.textLa: Charitas mea cum omnibus vobis in Christo Iesu. Amen.
